editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: As it was acted (With great applause) by the children of her majesty's revels in the black friars.
Written by Fra. Beaumont and Io. Fletcher, gent.
¶ Printed for Miles partridge, and are to be sold at his shop at the George near st. Dunston's church in Fleetstreet. 1616.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter the two Louelesses, Savill the steward, and a page.

sp.speaker: Elder Lou.
sp.p: Brother, is your last hope passed to mollify Moorecraft's heart about your mortgage?

sp.speaker: Young Loue.
sp.p: Hopelessly passed: I have presented the usurer with a richer draught, then ever Cleopatra swallowed; he hath sucked in ten thousand pounds worth of my land, more than he paid for at a gulp, without trumpets.

sp.speaker: Elder 〈◊〉.
sp.p: I have as hard a task to perform in this house.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Faith mine was to make a usurer honest, or to lose my land.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: And mine is to persuade a passionate woman, or to leave the land.
Savill make the boat stay, I fear I shall begin my unfortunate journey this night, though the darkness of the night and the roughness of the waters might easily dissuade an unwilling man.

sp.speaker: Sauil.
sp.p: Sir, your father's old friends hold it the sounder course for your body and estate, to stay at home, and marry, and propagate, and govern in your country, than to travel for diseases, and return following the court in a nightcap, and die without issue.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p:
Savill, you shall gain the opinion of a better
servant, in seeking to execute, not alter my will, howsoever my intents succeed.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Yonder's mistress Yonglove brother, the grave rubber of your mistress toes.

div.stage: Enter mistress Yonglove the waiting woman.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Mistress Yonglove.

sp.speaker: Young
sp.p: Mr. Lovelesse, truly we thought your sails had been hoist: my mistress is persuaded you are sea-sick ere this.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Loves she her ill taken up resolution so dear? Didst thou move her for me?

sp.speaker: Young
sp.p: By this light that shines, there's no removing her, if she get a stiff opinion by the end. I attempted her today when they say a woman can deny nothing.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: What critical minute was that?

sp.speaker: Young
sp.p: When her smock was over her ears: but she was no more pliant than if it hung about her heels.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I prithee deliver my service, and say I desire to see the dear cause of my banishment; and then for France.

sp.speaker: Young
sp.p: I'll do't: hark hither, is that your brother?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Yes, have you lost your memory?

sp.speaker: Young
sp.p: As I live he's a pretty fellow.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: O this is a sweet brach.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Why she knows not you.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: No, but she offered me once to know her: to this day she loves youth of eighteen; she heard a tale how Cupid struck her in love with a great lord in the tiltyard, but he never saw her; yet she in kindness would needs wear a willow garland at his wedding. She loved all the players in the last Queen's time once over: she was struck when they acted lovers, and forsook some when they played murderers. She has nine spur-royals, and the servants say she hoards old gold; and she herself pronounces angrily, that the farmer's eldest son, or her mistress husband's clerk that shall be, that marries her, shall make her a jointure of fourscore pounds a year; she tells tales of the serving-men.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Enough, I know her brother. I shall entreat you only to salute my mistress, and take leave, we'll part at the stairs.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Now sir, this first part of your will is performed: what's the rest?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: First let me beg your notice for this gentleman my brother.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I shall take it as a favour done to me, though the gentleman hath received but an untimely grace from you, yet my charitable disposition would have been ready to have done him freer courtesies as a stranger, than upon those cold commendations.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Lady, my salutations crave acquaintance and leave at once.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Sir I hope you are the master of your own occasions.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Would I were so. Mistress, for me to praise over again that worth, which all the world, and you yourself can see.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: It's a cold Rome this; servant.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: What think you if I have a chimney fort out here?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Mistress another in my place, that were not tied to believe all your actions just, would apprehend himself wronged: but I, whose virtues are constancy and obedience.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Yonglove, make a good fire above to warm me after my servant's exordiums.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I have heard and seen your affability to be such, that the servants you give wages to may speak.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 'Tis true, 'tis true; but they speak toth' purpose.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Mistress your will leads my speeches from the purpose. But as a man —

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: A simile servant? This room was built for honest meaners, that deliver themselves hastily and plainly, and are gone. Is this a time or place for exordiums, and similes, and metaphors? If you have ought to say, break into't; my answers shall very reasonably meet you.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Mistress I came to see you.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: That's happily dispatched, the next.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: To take leave of you.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: To be gone?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You need not have despaired of that, nor have used so many circumstances to win me to give you leave to perform my command: is there a third.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Yes, I had a third, had you been apt to hear it.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I never apter. Fast (Good servant) fast.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: 'Twas to entreat you to hear reason.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Most willingly, have you brought one can speak it?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Lastly, it is to kindle in that barren heart love and forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You would stay at home?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Yes lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why you may, and doubtlessly will, when you have debated that your commander is but your mistress, a woman, a weak one, wildly overborne with passions: but the thing by her commanded, is to see Dover's dreadful cliff, passing in a poor water-house; the dangers of the merciless merciless twixt that and Callis, five long hours sail, with three poor weeks victuals.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: You wrong me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Then to land dumb, unable to inquire for an English host, to remove from city to city, by most chargeable post-horse, like one that rod in quest of his mother tongue.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo
sp.p: You wrong me much.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: And all these (Almost invincible labours) performed for your mistress to be in danger to for her, and to put on new allegiance to some French lady, who is content to change language with you for laughter, and after your whole year spent in tennis and broken speech, to stand to the hazard of being laughed at at your return, and have tales made on you by the chambermaids.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: You wrong me much.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Lowder yet.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: You know your least word is of force to make me seek out dangers, move me not with toys: but in this banishment, I must take leave to say, you are unjust: was one kiss forced from you in public by me so unpardonable? why all the hours of day and night have seen us kiss.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 'Tis true, and so you satisfied the company that heard me chide.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Your own eyes were not dearer to you than I?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: And so you told 'em.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I did, yet no sign of disgrace need to have stained your cheek: you yourself knew your pure and simple heart to be most unspotted, and free from the least baseness.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I did: but if a maids heart doth but once think that she is suspected, her own face will write her guilty.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: But where lay this disgrace? The world that knew us, knew our resolutions well: and could it be hoped that I should give away my freedom, and venture a perpetual bondage with one I never kissed? or could I in 〈◊〉 wisdom take too much love upon me, from her that chose me for her husband?

lg.l: Believe me; if my wedding smock were on,
Were the gloves bought and given, the licence come,
Were the rosemary branches dipped, and all
The hipochrists and cakes 〈◊〉 and drunk off,
Were these two arms encompassed with the hands
Of bachelors, to lead me to the church;
Were my feet in the door, were I John, said,
If John should boast a favour done by me,
I would not wed that year: and you I hope,
When you have spent his year commodiously,
In achieving languages, will at your return
Acknowledge me more coy of parting with mine eyes,
Than such a friend. More talk I hold not now,
If you dare go!

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I dare you know; first let me kiss.

lg.l: Farewell sweet servant, your talk performed,
On a new ground as a beginning suitor,
I shall be apt to hear you.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Farewell cruel mistress.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Brother you'll hazard the losing your tide to Gravesend: you have a long half mile by land to Greenwich.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I go: but brother, what yet unheard of course to live, doth your imagination flatter you with? your ordinary means are devoured.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Course? why horse-coursing I think. Consume no time in this: I have no estate to be mended by meditation: he that busies himself about my fortunes, may properly be said to busy himself about nothing.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Yet some course you must take, which for my satisfaction resolve and open: if you will shape none, I must inform you, that that man but persuades himself he means to live, that imagines not the means.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Why live upon others, as others have lived upon me.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I apprehend not that: you have fed others, and consequently disposed of 'em: and the same measure must you expect from your maintainers, which will be too heavy an alteration for you to bear.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Why I'll purse; if that raise me not, I'll bet at bowling-alleys, or man whores; I would fain live by others: but I'll live whilst I am unhanged, and after the thoughts taken.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I see you are tide to no particular employment then.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Faith I may choose my course: they say nature brings forth none but she provides for 'em: I'll try her liberality.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Well, to keep your feet out of base and dangerous paths, I have resolved you shall live as master of my house. It shall be your care Savill to see him fed and clothed, not according to his present estate, but to his birth and former fortunes.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: If it be referred to him, if I be not found in carnation jersey stockings, blue devils breeches, with three guards down, and my pocket ith' sleeves, I'll ne'er look you i'th face again.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: A comelier wear I wiss it is then those dangling slops.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: To keep you ready to do him all service peaceably, and him to command you reasonably, I leave these further directions in writing, which at your best leisure together open and read.

div.stage: Enter Yonglove to them with a jewel.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Sir my Mr. s. commends her love to you in this token, and these words; it is a jewel (She says) which as a favour from her she would request you to wear till your year's travel be performed: which once expired, she will hastily expect your happy return.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Return my service with such thanks, as she may imagine the heart of a suddenly overjoyed man would willingly utter: and you (I hope) I shall with slender arguments persuade to wear this diamond, that when my mistress shall through my long absence, and the approach of new suitors, offer to forget me; you may call your eye down to your finger, and remember and speak of me: she will hear thee better than those allied by birth to her; as we see many men much swayed by the grooms of their chambers, not that they have a greater part of their love or opinion on them, as on others, but for they know their secrets.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: A my credit I swear, I think 'twas made for me: fear no other suitors.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I shall not need to teach you how to discredit their beginnings, you know how to take exception at their shirts at washing, or to make the maids swear they found plasters in their beds.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I know, I know, and do not you fear the suitors.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Farewell, be mindful and be happy: the night calls me.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: The gods of the winds befriend you sir: a constant and a liberal lover thou art; more such God send us.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Let 'em not stand still, we have rid hard.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: A suitor I know by his riding hard, I'll not be seen.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: A pretty hall this, no servant in't? I would look freshly.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: You have delivered your errand to me then: there's no danger in a handsome young fellow: I'll show myself.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Lady may it please you to bestow upon a stranger the ordinary grace of salutation: are you the lady of this house?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Sir, I am worthily proud to be a servant of hers.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Lady I should be as proud to be a servant of yours, did not my so late acquaintance make me despair.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Sir, it is not so hard to achieve, but nature may bring it about.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: For these comfortable words I remain your glad debtor. Is your lady at home?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: She is no straggler sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: May her occasions admit me to speak with her?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: If you come in the way of a suitor, no.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I know your affable virtue will be moved to persuade her, that a gentleman benighted and strayed offers to be bound to her for a night's lodging.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I will commend this message to her: but if you aim at her body, you will be deluded: other women the households of good carriage and government; upon any of which if you can cast your affection, they will perhaps be found as faithful, and not so coy.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What a skin full of lust is this? I thought I had come a-wooing, and I am the courted party. This is right court fashion: men, women, and all woe; catch that catch may. If this soft hearted woman have infused any of her tenderness into her lady, there is hope she will be pliant. But who's here?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: God save you sir, my lady lets you know she desires to be acquainted with your name before she confer with you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sir my name calls me Welford.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Sir, you are a gentleman of a good name. I'll try his wit.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I will uphold it as good as any of my ancestors had this two hundred years sir.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I knew a worshipful and a religious gentleman of your name in the bishopric of Durham. Call you him cousin?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I am only allied to his virtue's sir.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: It is modestly said: I should carry the badge of your christianity with me to.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What's that, a cross? there's a tester.

sp.speaker: Ro
sp.p: I mean the name which your godfathers and godmothers gave you at the font.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: 'Tis Harry: but you cannot proceed orderly now in your catechism: for you have told me who gave me that name. Shall beg your names.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Roger.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What room fill you in this house?

sp.speaker: Ro
sp.p: More rooms than one.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: The more the merrier. But may my boldness know, why your lady hath sent you to decipher my name?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Her own words were these; to know whether you were a formerly denied suitor, disguised in this message: for I can assure you she delights not in thalame: Hymen and she are at variance, I shall return with much haste.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And much speed sir I hope: certainly I am arrived amongst a nation of new found fools: on a land where no navigator has yet planted wit, if I had foreseen it, I would have jaded my breeches with bells, knives, copper and glasses to trade with the women for their virginities: yet I fear I should have betrayed myself to an 〈◊〉 charge then: here's the walking nightcap again.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Sir, my lady's pleasure is to see you: who hath commanded me to acknowledge her sorrow. that you must take the pains to come up for so bad entertainment.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I shall obey your lady that sent it, and acknowledge you that brought it to be your art's master.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I am but a bachelor of art sir; and I have the mending of all under this roof, from my lady on her down bed, to the maid in the pease straw.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: A cobbler sir?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: No sir. I inculcate divine service within these walls,

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: But the inhabitants of this house do often employ you on errands, without any scruple of conscience.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Yes, I do take the air many mornings on foot, three or four miles for eggs: but why move you that?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: To know whether it might become your function to bid my man to neglect his horse a little, to attend on me.

sp.speaker: Ro
sp.p: Most properly sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I pray ye do so then: and whilst I will attend your lady. You direct all this house in the true way?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I do sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And this door (I hope) conducts to your lady?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Your understanding is ingenious.

div.stage: Ent. young Loveless and Savill with a writing.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: By your favour sir you shall pardon me.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: I shall beat your favour sir, cross me no more; I say they shall come in.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Sir you forget one, who I am.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Sir I do not; thou art my brother's steward, his cast off mill-money, his kitchen arithmetic.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Sir I hope you will not make so little of me.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: I make thee not so little as thou art: for indeed there goes no more to the making of a steward, but a fair imprimis, and then a reasonable item infused into him, and the thing is done.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Nay then you stir my duty, and I must tell you.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: What wouldst thou tell me, how hops go, or hold some rotten discourse of sheep, or when our lady day falls? Prithee farewell, and entertain my friends, be drunk, and burn thy table-books: and my dear spark of velvet thou and I

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good sir remember.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: I do remember thee a foolish fellow, one that did put his trust in almanacs, and horse-faiers, and rose by honey and pot-butter. Shall they come in yet?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Nay then I must unfold your brother's pleasure, these be the lessons sir, he left behind him.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Prithee expound the first.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I leave to keep my house 300 pounds a year; and my brother to dispose of it.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Mark that my wicked steward, and I dispose of it.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Whilst he bears himself like a gentleman, and my credit falls not in him. Mark that my good young sir, mark that.

sp.speaker: Young Lo
sp.p: Nay if it be no more I shall fulfil it: whilst my legs will carry me I'll bear myself gentlemanlike, but when I am drunk, let them bear me that can. Forward dear steward.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Next it is my will, that he be furnished (As my brother) with attendance, apparel, and the obedience of my people.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Steward this is as plain as your old minikin breeches. Your wisdom will relent now, will it not? Be mollified or — you understand me sir, proceed.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Next, that my steward keep his place, and power, and bound my brother's wildness with his care.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: I'll hear no more this apocrypha, bind it by itself steward.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: This is your brother's will, and as I take it, he makes no mention of such company as you would draw unto you. Captains of gallifoists, such as in a clear day have seen Callis, fellows that have no more of God, than their oaths comes to: they wear swords to reach fire at a play, and get there the oyld end of a pipe for their guerdon: then the remnant of your regiment are wealthy tobacco merchants, that set up with one ounce, and break for three; together with a forlorn hope of poets, and all these look like Carthusians, things without linen: are these fit company for my master's brother?

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p:
I will either convert thee (Oh thou pagan steward)
or presently confound thee and thy reckonings, who's there? call in the gent.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Nay you shall know both who I am, and where I am.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Are you my master's brother?

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Are you the sage master steward, with a face like an old ephemerides?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Then God help all, I say.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Ay, and 'tis well said my old peer of France: welcome gentlemen, welcome gentlemen; mine own dear lads, you're richly welcome. Know this old harry-groat.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Sir I will take your love.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Sir you will take my purse.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And study to continue it.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I do believe you.

sp.speaker: Traveler
sp.p: Your honourable friend and master's brother, hath given you to us for a worthy fellow, and so we hug you sir.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Has given himself into the hands of varlets, not to be carved out. Sir are these the pieces?

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: They are the morals of the age, the virtues. Men made of gold.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Of your gold you mean sir.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: This is a man of war, that cries go on; and wears his colours.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: In's nose.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: In the fragrant field. This is a traveller sir, knows men and manners, and has ploughed up the sea so far, till both the poles have knocked, has seen the sun take coach, and can distinguish the colour of his horses, and their kinds, and had a Flanders mare leapt there.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: 'Tis much.

sp.speaker: Traveler
sp.p: I have seen more sir.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p:
'Tis even enough a conscience; sit down, and rest you, you are at the end of the world already. Would you had as good a living sir as this fellow could
lie you out of has a notable gift in't.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: This ministers the smoke, and this the Muses.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: And you the clothes, and meat, and money, you have a goodly generation of 'em, pray let 'em multiply, your brother's house is big enough, and to say truth, has too much land, hang it dirt.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Why now thou art a loving stinkard. Fire off thy annotations and thy rent books; thou hast a weak brain Savill, and with the next long bill thou wilt run mad. Gentlemen you are once more welcome to three hundred pounds a year; we will be freely merry, shall we not?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Merry as mirth, and wine my lovely Lovelesse.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: A serious look shall be a jury to excommunicate any man from our company.

sp.speaker: Traveler
sp.p: We will have nobody talk wisely neither.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: What think you gentlemen by all this revenue in drink?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I am all for drink.

sp.speaker: Traveler
sp.p: I am dry till it be so.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: He that will not cry amen to this, let him live sober, seem wise, and die ath' corum.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: It shall be so, we'll have it all in drink, let meat and lodging go, they're transitory, and show men merely mortal: then we'll have wenches, every one his wench, and every week a fresh one: we'll keep no powdered flesh: all these we have by warrant under the title of things necessary. Here upon this place I ground it: the obedience of my people, and all necessaries: your opinions gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: 'Tis plain and evident that he meant wenches.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good sir let me expound it.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Here be as sound men as yourself sir.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: This do I hold to be the interpretation of it; in this word necessary, is concluded all that be helps to man: woman was made the first, and therefore here the chiefest.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Believe me 'tis a learned one, and by these words; the obedience of my people, (You steward being one) are bound to fetch us wenches.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: He is, he is.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Steward attend us for instructions.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: But will you keep no house sir?

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Nothing but drink, three hundred pounds in drink.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: O miserable house, and miserable I that live to see it. Good sir keep some meat.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Get us good whores, and for your part, I'll board you in an alehouse, you shall have cheese and onions.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: What shall become of me, no chimney smoking? Well prodigal, your brother will come home.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Come lads I'll warrant you for wenches, three hundred pounds in drink.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter lady, her sister Martha, Welford, Yonglove, and others.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Sir now you see your bad lodging, I must bid you good-night.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Lady if there be any want, 'tis in want of you.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: A little sleep will ease that compliment. Once more good night.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Once more dear lady, and then all sweet nights.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Dear sir be short and sweet then.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Shall the morrow prove better to me, shall I hope my suit happier by this night's rest.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Is your suit so sickly that rest will help it? Pray ye let it rest then till I call for it. Sir as a stranger you have had all my welcome: but had I known your errand ere you came, your passage had been straighter: sir, good night.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: So fair, and cruel, dear unkind good-night.
Nay sir you shall stay with me, I'll press your zeal so far.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: O lord sir,

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Do you love tobacco?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Surely I love it, but it loves not me; yet with your reverence I'll be bold.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Pray light it sir. How do you like it.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I promise you it is notable stinging gear indeed. It is wet sir, lord how it brings down rheum?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Handle it again sir; you have a warm text of it.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Thanks ever premised for it. I promise you it is very powerful, and by a trope, spiritual: for certainly it moves in sundry places.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Ay, it does so sir, and me especially to ask sir, why you wear a night cap.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Assuredly I will speak the truth unto you; you shall understand sir, that my head is broken, and by whom; even by that visible beast the butler.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: The butler? certainly he had all his drink about him when he did it. Strike one of your grave cassock? The offence sir?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Reproving him at tra-trip sir, for swearing: you have the total surely.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You told him when his rage was set a-tilt, and so he cracked your cannons. I hope he has not hurt your gentle reading: but shall we see these gentlewomen tonight ?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Have patience sir, until our fellow Nicholas be deceased, that is, asleep : for so the word is taken; to sleep to die, to die to sleep: a very figure sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Cannot you cast another for the gentlewomen?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Not till the man be in his bed, his grave; his grave, his bed; the very same again sir. Our comic poet gives the reason sweetly; plenus rimarum est, he is full of loopholes, and will discover to our patroness.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Your comment sir has made me understand you.

div.stage: Enter Maria the lady's sister, and Yonglove to them with a posset.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Sir be addressed, the graces do salute you with the full bowl of plenty. Is our old enemy entombed?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: He's fast?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: And does he snore out supinely with the poet?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, he out-snores the poet.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Gentlewoman, this courtesy shall bind a stranger to you, ever your servant.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, my sister's strictness makes not us forget you are a stranger and a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: In sooth sir were I changed into into my lady, a gentleman so well endued with parts, should not be lost.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I thank you gentlewoman, and rest bound to you. See how this foul familiar chews the cud: from thee and three and fifty, good love deliver me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Will you sit down sir, and take a spoon?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I take it kindly lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It is our best banquet sir.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Shall we give thank,?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I have to the gentlewoman already sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Good sir Roger keep that breath to cool your part o'th posset, you may chance have a scalding zeal else: and you will needs be doing, pray tell your twenty to yourself. Would you could like this sir?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I would your sister would like me as well lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sure sir she would not eat you: but banish that imagination; she's only wedded to herself, lies with herself, and loves herself; and for another husband then herself, he may knock at the gate, but ne'er come in: be wise sir, she's a woman, and a trouble, and has her many faults, the least of which is, she cannot love you.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: God pardon her, she'll do worse, would I were worthy his least grief mistress Martha.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Now I must overhear her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Faith would thou hadst them all withal my heart: I do not think they would make thee a day older.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Sir will you put in deeper, 'tis the sweeter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well said old sayings.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: She looks like one indeed. Gentlewoman you keep your word, your sweet self has made the bottom sweeter.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Sir I begin a frolic, dare you change sir?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
Myself for you, so please you. That smile has turned my stomach. This is right the old emblem of the
moil cropping off thistles: lord what a hunting head she carries, sure she has been ridden with a martingale. Now love deliver me.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Do I dream, or do I wake? surely I know not: am I rubbed off? is this the way of all my morning's prayers? O Roger, thou art but grass, and woman as a flower. Did I for this consume my quarters in meditation, vows, and wooed her in heroical epistles? Did I expound the owl, and undertook, with labour and expense the recollection of those thousand pieces, consumed in cellars and tobacco shops of that our honoured Englishman ni. Br.? Have I done this, and am I done thus too? I will end with the wiseman, and say, he that holds a woman, has an eel by the tail.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis so late, and our entertainment (Meaning our posset) by this is grown so cold, that 'twere an unmannerly part longer to hold you from your rest: let what the house has be at your command sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sweet rest be with you lady; and to you what you desire too.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: It should be some such good thing like yourself then.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Heaven keep me from that curse, and all my issue. Good night antiquity.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Solamen miseris socios habuisse doloris: but I alone.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Learned sir, will you bid my man come to me? and requesting a greater measure of your learning, good night, good Mr. Roger.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Good sir, peace be with you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Adieu dear dominae. Half a dozen such in a kingdom would make a man forswear confession: for who that had but half his wits about him would commit the counsel of a serious sin to such a cruel nightcap?
Why how now, shall we have an antique?
Whose head do you carry upon your shoulders, that you jowl it so against the post? Is't for your ease? or have you seen the seller? Where are my slippers sir?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Where sir? have you got the pot verdugo? have you seen the horse's sir?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Have they any meat?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Faith sir they have a kind of wholesome rushes, hay I cannot call it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And no provender?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Sir so I take it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You are merry sir, and why so?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Faith sir, here are no oats to be got, unless you'll have 'em in porridge: the people are so mainly given to spoonmeat: yonder's a cast of coach-mares of the gentlewomans, the strangest cattle.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Why they are transparent sir, you may see through them: and such a house?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Come sir, the truth of your discovery.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Sir they are in tribes like Jews: the kitchen and the dairy make one tribe, and have their faction and their fornication within themselves; the buttery and the laundry are another, and there's no love lost; the chambers are entire, and what's done there, is somewhat higher than my knowledge; but this I am sure, between these copulations, a stranger is kept virtuous, that is, fasting. But of all this the drink sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What of that sir?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Faith sir I will handle it as the time and your patience will give me leave. This drink, or this cooling julip, of which three spoonfuls kills the calenture, a pint breeds the cold palsy.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sir you bely the house.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I would I did sir. But as I am a true man, if 'twere but one degree colder, nothing but an ass's hoof would hold it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I am glad on't sir: for if it had proved stronger, you had been tongue-tied of these commendations. Light me the candle sir, I'll hear no more.

div.stage: Enter young Loveless and his comrades, with wenches, and two fydlers.

lg.l: Come my brave man of war, trace out thy darling,
And you my learned council, set and turn boys
Kiss till the cow come home, kiss close, kiss close knave s.
My modern poet, thou shalt kiss in couplets. Ent. with wine.
Strike up you merry varlets, and leave your peeping,
this is no pay for fiddlers.
O my dear boy, thy Hercules, thy captain
Makes thee his Hilas, his delight, his solace.
Love thy brave man of war, and let thy bounty
Clap him in chamois: let there be deducted out of our main potation
Five marks in hatchments to adorn this thigh,
Cramped with this rest of peace, and I will fight
Thy battles.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Thou shalt have't boy, and sly in feather, lead on a march you michers.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: O my head, oh my heart, what a noise and change is here; would I had been cold ith' mouth before this day, and ne'er have lived to see this dissolution. He that lives within a mile of this place, had as good sleep in the perpetual noise of an iron mill. There's a dead sea of drink ith' cellar, in which goodly vessels lie wrecked, and in the middle of this deluge appears the tops of flagons and black jacks, like churches drown ith' marshes.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: What art thou come? My sweet sir Amias welcome to Troy. Come thou shalt kiss my Helen, and court her in a dance.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good sir consider.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Shall we consider gentlemen. How say you?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Consider? that were a simple toy i'faith, consider? whose morals that? The man that cries consider, is our foe: let my steel know him.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Stay thy dead doing hand, he must not die yet: prithee be calm my Hector.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Peasant, slave, thou groom, composed of grudgeings, live and thank this gentleman, thou hadst seen Pluto else. The next consider kills thee.

sp.speaker: Traveler
sp.p: Let him drink down his word again in a gallon of sack.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: 'Tis but a snuff, make it two gallons, and let him do it kneeling in repentance.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Nay rather kill me, there's but a layman lost. Good captain do your office.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p:
Thou shalt drink steward, drink and dance my steward. Strike him a hornpipe 〈◊〉, take thy striver,
and pace her till she stew.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Sure sir I cannot dance with your gentlewoman, they are too light for me, pray break my head, and let me go.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: He shall dance, he shall dance.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: He shall dance, and drink, and be drunk and dance, and be drunk again, and shall see no meat in a year.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: And three quarters.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: And three quarters be it.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Who knocks there? let him in.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Some to deliver me I hope.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Gentlemen, God save you all, my business is to one Mr. Lovelesse.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: This is the gentleman you mean; view him, and take his inventory, he's a right one.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: He promises no less sir.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Sir your business?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Sir, I should let you know, yet I am loath, yet I am sworn to't, would some other tongue would speak it for me.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Out with it a god's name.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: All I desire sir is, the patience and sufferance of a man, and good sir be not moved more,

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Then a pottle of sack will do, here's my hand, prithee thy business?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Good sir excuse me, and whatsoever you hear, think, must have been known unto you, and be yourself discreet; and bear it nobly.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Prithee dispatch me.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Your brother's dead sir.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Thou dost not mean dead drunk?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: No, no, dead and drowned at sea sir.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Art sure he's dead?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Too sure sir.

sp.speaker: Young Lo
sp.p: Ay, but art thou very certainly sure of it?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: As sure sir as I tell it.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: But art thou sure he came not up again?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: He may come up, but never to call you brother.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: But art sure he had water enough to drown him?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Sure sir he wanted none.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: I would not have him want, I loved him better; here I forgive thee: and i'faith be plain, how do I bear it?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Very wisely sir.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Fill him some wine. Thou dost not see me moved, these transitory toys ne'er trouble me, he's in a better place my friend, I know't. Some fellows would have cried now, and have cursed thee, and fallen out with their meat, and kept a pother; but all this helps not, he was too good for us, and let God keep him: there's the right use on't friend. Off with thy drink, thou hast a spice of sorrow makes thee dry: fill him another, Savill, your masters dead, and who am I now Savill? Nay, let's all bear it well, wipe, Savill, wipe, tears are but thrown away: we shall have wenches now, shall we not Savill? Drink to my friend captain.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: And drink innumerable.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Yes forsooth sir.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: And you'll strain curtsy and be drunk a little.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I would be glad, sir, to do my weak endeavour.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: You may be brought in time to love a wench too.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: In time the sturdy oak sir.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Some more wine for my friend there.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I shall be drunk anon for my good news: but I have a loving brother, that's my comfort.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Here's to you sir, this is the worst I wish you for your news: and if I had another elder brother, and say it were his chance to feed more fishes, I should be still the same you see me now, a poor contented gentleman. More wine for my friend there, he's dry again.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I shall be if I follow this beginning. Well, my dear brother, if I scape this drowning, 'tis your turn next to sink, you shall duck twice before I help you. Sir I cannot drink more, pray let me have your pardon.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p:
O lord sir, 'tis your modesty: more wine, give him a bigger glass; hug him my captain, thou shalt
be my chief mourner.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And this my pennon. Sir a full rouse to you, and to my lo. of land here.

sp.speaker: Elder Lou.
sp.p: I feel a buzzing in my brains, pray God they bear this out, and I'll ne'er trouble them so far again. Here's to you sir.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: To my dear steward, down a your knees you infidel, you pagan; be drunk and penitent.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Forgive me sir and I'll be any thing.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Then be a bawd: I'll have thee a brave bawd.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Sir I must take my leave of you, my business is so urgent.

sp.speaker: Young Lo:
sp.p: Let's have a bridling cast before you go. Fills a new stoup.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I dare not sir by no means.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Have you any mind to a wench? I would fain gratify you for the pains you took sir.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: As little as to the tother.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: If you find any stirring, do but say so.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Sir you are too bounteous, when I find that itching, you shall assuage it sir before another: this only, and farewell sir. Your brother when the storm was most extreme, told all about him, he left a will, which lies close behind a chimney in the matted chamber: and so as well sir, as you have made me able, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Let us embrace him all: if you grow dry before you end your business, pray take a bait here, I have a fresh hogshead for you.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: You shall neither will nor choose sir. My master is a wonderful fine gentleman has a fine state, a very fine state sir, I am his steward sir, and his man.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Would you were your own sir, as I left you. Well I must cast about, or all sinks.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Farewell gentleman, gentleman. Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: What would you with me sir?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Farewell gentleman.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: O sleep sir, sleep.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Well boys, you see what's fallen, let's in and drink, and give thanks for it.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Let's give thanks for't.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Drunk as I live.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Drunk as I live boys.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Why now thou art able to discharge thine office, and cast up a reckoning of some weight; I will be knighted, for my state will bear it, 'tis sixteen hundred boys: off with your husks, I'll skin you all in satin.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: O sweet Lovelesse!

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: All in satin? O sweet Lovelesse.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: March in my noble compeers: and this my countess shall be led by two: and so proceed we to the will.

div.stage: Enter Moorecraft the usurer, and widow.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: And widow, as I say be your own friend: your husband left you wealthy, I and wise, continue so sweet duck, continue so. Take heed of young smooth varlets, younger brothers, they are worms that will eat through your bags: they are very lightning, that with a slash or two will melt your money, and never sing your purse strings: they are colts, wench, colts, heady and dangerous, till we take 'em up, and make 'em fit for bonds; look upon me, I have had, and have yet matter of moment girl, matter of moment; you may meet with a worse back, I'll not commend it.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Nor I neither sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Yet thus far by your favour widow, 'tis tough.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: And therefore not for my diet, for I love a tender one.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Sweet widow leave your frumps, and be edified: you know my state, I sell no perspectives, scarves, gloves, nor hangers, nor put my trust in shoe-ties: and where your husband in an age was rising by burned figs, dredged with meal and powdered sugar, sanders and grains, wormseed and rotten reasons, and such vile tobacco, that made the footmen mangy; I in a year have put up hundreds enclosed, my widow, those pleasant meadows, by a forfeit mortgage: for which the poor knight takes a lone chamber, owes for his ale, and dare nor beat his hostess: nay more —

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Good sir no more, whate'er my husband was, I know what I am, and if you marry me, you must bear it bravely off sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Not with the head, sweet widow.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: No, sweet sir, but with your shoulders: I must have you dubbed, for under that I will stoop a feather. My husband was a fellow loved to toil, feed ill, made gain his exercise, and so grew costive, which for I was his wife, and gave way to, and spun mine own smock's course, and sir, so little; but let that pass. Time, that wears all things out, wore out this husband, who in penitence of such fruitless five years marriage, left me great with his wealth, which if you'll be á worthy gossip to, be knighted sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Now sir, from whom come you? whose man are you sir?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Sir, I come from young Mr. Lovelesse.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Be silent sir, I have no money, not a penny for you, he's sunk, your master's sunk, a perished man sir.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Indeed his brother's sunk sir, God be with him, a perished man indeed, and drowned at sea.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: How saidst thou, good my friend, his brother drowned?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Untimely, sir, at sea.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: And thy young master left sole heir?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: And he wants money?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Yes, and sent me to you; for he is now to be knighted.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Widow, be wise, there's more land coming, widow be very wise, and give thanks for me widow.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Be you very wise, and be knighted, and then give thanks for me sir.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: What says your worship to this money?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I say, he may have money if he please.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: A thousand sir?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: A thousand sir, provided any wise sir, his land lie for the payment, otherwise —

div.stage: Enter young Loveless and Comrades to them.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: He's here himself sir, and can better tell you.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: My notable dear friend, and worthy Mr. Lovelesse, and now right worshipful, all joy and welcome.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Thanks to my dear encloser, Mr. Moorecraft; prithee old angel gold, salute my family, I'll do as much for yours; this, and your own desires, fair gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: And yours sir, if you mean well; 'tis a handsome gentleman.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Sirrah, my brother's dead.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Dead?

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Dead, and by this time soused for ember week.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Dead?

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Drowned, drowned at sea: man, by the next fresh conger that comes we shall hear more.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Now by the faith of my body it moves me much.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: What, wil't thou be an ass, and weep for the dead? why I thought nothing but a general inundation would have moved thee: prithee be quiet, he hath left his land behind him.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: O, has he so?

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Yes faith, I thank him for't, I have all boy, hast any ready money?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Will you sell sir?

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: No not outright good gripe; marry, a mortgage, or such a slight security.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I have no money sir for mortgage; if you will sell, and all or none, I'll work a new mine for you.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good sir look afore you, he'll work you out of all else: if you sell all your land, you have sold your country, and than you must to sea to seek your brother, and there lie pickled in a poudering tub, and break your teeth with biscuits and hard beef that must have watering sir: and where's your 300. pounds a year in drink then? If you're tun up the straits you may, for you have no calling for drink there, but with a cannon, nor no scoring but on your ships sides, and then if you scape with life, and take a faggot boat, and a bottle of Usquebaugh, come home poor men, like a type of Thames street stinking of pitch and poor John. I cannot tell sir, I would be ●th to s● 〈◊〉 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p:
Steward, you are an ass, a measeled mongrel, and were it not again the peace of my sovereign friend here, I would break your forecasting coxcomb, dog I would, even with thy staff of office there, thy pen and inkhorn. Noble boy, the god of gold here has said thee well, take money for thy 〈◊〉: 〈◊〉 and believe, thou art cold of constiution, thy seat unhealthful, sell and be wise; we are three that will adorn thee,
and live according to thine own heart child: mirth shall be only ours, and only ours shall be the black eyed beauties of the time. Money makes men eternal.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: Do what you will, 'tis the noblest course, than you may live without the charge of people, only we four will make a family, I and an age that shall beget new annals, in which I'll write thy life my son of pleasure, equal with Nero or Caligula.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: What mean they captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Two roaring boys of Rome that made all split.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Come sir, what dare you give?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: You will not sell sir?

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Who told you so sir?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good sir have a care.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Peace, or I'll tack your tongue up to your roof. What money? speak.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Six thousand pound sir.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Take it, has overbidden by the sun: bind him to his bargain quickly.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Come, strike me luck with earnest, and draw the writings.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: There's a god's penny for thee.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Sir, for my old master's sake let my farm be excepted, if I become his tenant I am undone, my children beggars, and my wife God knows what: consider me dear sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I'll have all in or none.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: All in, all in: dispatch the writings.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Go, thou art a pretty forehanded fellow, would thou wert wiser.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Now do I sensibly begin to feel myself a rascal: would I could teach a school, or beg, or lie well, I am utterly undone; now he that taught thee to deceive and cousin, take thee to his mercy: so be it.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Come widow, come, never stand upon a knighthood, 'tis a mere paper honour, and not proof enough for a sergeant. Come, come, I'll make thee —

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: To answer in short, 'tis this sir, no knight, no widow: if you make me any thing, it must be a lady; and so I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Farewell sweet widow, and think of it.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Sir I do more than think of it, it makes me dream sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: She's rich and sober, if this itch were from her: and say I be at charge to pay the footmen, and the trumpet, I and the horsemen too, and be a knight, and she refuse me then: then am I hoist into the subsidy, and so by consequence should prove a coxcomb: I'll have a care of that. Six thousand pound, and then the land is mine, there's some refreshing yet.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: If he but follow me, as all my hopes tells me he's man enough, up goes my rest, and I know I shall draw him.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: This is the strangest pampered piece of flesh towards fifty, that ever frailty coped withal, what a trim envoy here she has put upon me: these women are a proud kind of cattle, and love this whoreson doing so directly, that they will not stick to make their very skins bawds to their flesh. Here's dogskin and storax sufficient to kill a hawk: what to do with it, beside nailing it up amongst Irish heads of Teere, to show the mightiness of her palm, I know not: there she is, I must enter into dialogue. Lady you have lost your glove.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Not sir if you have found it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: It was my meaning lady to restore it.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: 'Twill be uncivil in me to take back a favour, fortune hath so well bestowed sir, pray wear it for me.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I had rather wear a bell. But hark you mistress, what hidden virtue is there in this glove, that you would have me wear it? Is't good against sore eyes, or will it charm the toothache? Or these red tops, being steeped in white wine soluble, wil't kill the itch? or has it so concealed a providence to keep my hand from bo●ds? If it have none of these, and prove no more but a bare glove of half a crown a pair, 'twill be but half a courtesy, I wear two always: faith let's draw cuts, one will do me no pleasure.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p:
The tenderness of his years keeps him as yet in ignorance:
he's a well moulded fellow, and I wonder his blood should stir no higher; but 〈◊〉 his want of company: I must grow nearer to him.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: God save you both.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: And pardon you sir: this is somewhat rude, how came you hither?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Why through the doors, they are open.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What are you? and what business have you here?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: More I believe than you have.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Who would this fellow speak with? Art thou sober?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo
sp.p: Yes, I come not here to sleep.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Prithee what art thou?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: As much (Gay man) as thou art, I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Art thou no more?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Yes, more than thou dar'st be, a soldier.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Thou dost not come to quarrel?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: No, not with women; I come to speak here with a gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Why I am one.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: But not with one so gentle.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: This is a fine fellow.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Sir I am not fine yet, I am but new come over, direct me with your ticket to your tailor, and then I shall be fine sir. Lady, if there be a better of your sex within this house, say I would see her.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Why am not I good enough for you sir?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Your way you'll be too good, pray ●nd my business. This is another suitor: oh frail woman.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: This fellow with his bluntness hopes to do more than the long suits of a thousand could: though he be sour he's quick I must not trust him. Sir, this lady is not to speak with you, she is more serious: you smell as if you were new ralkt; go and be handsome, and than you may sit with her serving-men.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: What are you sir?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Guess by my outside.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Then I take you sir for some new silken thing weaned from the country, that shall (When you come to keep good company) be beaten into better manners. Pray good proud gentlewoman help me to your mistress.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: How many lives hast thou, that thou talkest thus rudely?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: But one, I am neither cat nor woman.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And will that one life sir maintain you ever in such bold sauciness?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Yes amongst a nation of such men as you are, and be no worse for wearing shall I speak with this lady?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: No by my troth shall not you.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I must stay here then.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: That you shall not neither.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Good fine thing tell me why.

lg.l: Good angry thing I'll tell you:
This is no place for such companions,
Such lousy gentlemen shall find their business
Better i'th the suburbs; there your strong pitch presume,
Mingled with lees of ale, shall reek in fashion:
This is no Thames street sir.
This gentleman informs you truly:
Prithee be satisfied, and seek the suburbs,
Good captain, or whatever title else,
The warlike eelboats have bestowed upon thee,
Go and reform thyself : prithee be sweeter,
And know my lady speaks with no such swabbers.
You cannot talk me out with your tradition
Of wit you pick from plays, go too, I have found ye:
And for you, tender sir, whose gentle blood
Runs in your nose, and makes you snuff at all
But three piled people, I do let you know,
He that be got your worship's satin suit,
Can make no men sir: I will see this lady,
And with the reverence of your silkenship,
In these old ornaments.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You will not sure.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Sure sir I shall.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: You would be beaten out.

lg.l: Indeed I would not, or if I would beaten,
Pray who shall beat me? this good gentleman
Looks as he were o'th peace.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sir you shall see that: will you get you out?

lg.l: Yes, that, that shall correct your boy's tongue,
Dare you fight? I will stay here still.
O their things are out, help, help for god's sake,
Madam; Jesus they foin at one another,
Madam, why who is within there? Enter lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Who breeds this rudeness?

lg.l: This uncivil fellow:
He says he comes from sea, where I believe
Has purged away his manners.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: What of him?

lg.l: Why he will rudely, without once God bless you,
Press to your privacies, and no denial
Must stand betwixt your person and his business;
I let go his ill language.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Sir, have you business with me?

lg.l: Madam some I have,
But not so serious to 〈◊〉 my life for't:
If you keep this quarter, and maintain about you
Such knights o'th sun 〈◊〉 this is, to defy
Men of 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 ye, you may live,
But in what some?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Pray stay sir, who has wronged you?

lg.l: Wrong me he cannot, though uncivilly
He 〈◊〉 his wild words at me: but to you
I think he did no honour, to deny
The haste I come withal, a passage to you,
Though I seem course.
Excuse me, gentle 〈◊〉, 'twas from my knowledge,
And shall have no protection. And to you sir,
You have showed more heat than wit, and from yourself
Have borrowed power, I never gave you here,
To do these wild unmanly things: my house
Is no blind street to swagger in: and my favours
Not doting yet on your unknown deserts
So far, that I should make you master of my business:
My credit yet, stands fairer with the people
Then to be tried with swords: and they that come
To do me service, must not think to win me
With hazard of a murder: if your love
consist in fury, carry it to the camp,
And there in honour of some common mistress,
Shorten your youth. I pray be better tempered,
And give me leave a while sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You must have it.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Now sir, your business?

lg.l: First I thank you for schooling this young fellow,
Whom his own follies, which is prone enough
Daily to fall into, if you but frown,
Shall level him away to his repentance:
Next I should rail at you, but you are a woman,
And anger lost upon you.
Why at me sir?
I never did you wrong, for to my knowledge
This is the first sight of you.
You have done that,
I must confess I have the least curse in,
Because the least acquaintance: but there be
(If there be honour in the minds of men)
Thousands, when they shall know what I deliver,
(As all good men must share 〈◊〉) will to shame
Blast your black memory.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: How is this good sir?

lg.l: 'Tis that, that if you have a soul will choke it:
You've killed a gentleman:

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I killed a gentleman?

lg.l: You and your cruelty have killed 〈◊〉 woman;
And such a man (Let me be angry in't)
Whose least worth weighed above all women's virtues
That are, I spare you all to come too: guess him now.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I am so innocent I cannot sir.

lg.l: Repent you mean: you are a perfect woman,
And as the first was, made for man's undoing.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Sir you have missed your way, I am not she.

lg.l: Would he had missed his way too, though he had
Wandered farther 〈◊〉 women are ill spoken of,
So he had 〈◊〉 this misery, you lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: How do you do sir?

lg.l: 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 I hope,
while I can keep myself from such temptations.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Pray leap into this matter, whither would ye?

lg.l: You had a servant that your peevishness
Enjoined to travel.
Such a one I have
〈◊〉, and should be grieved 'twere otherwise.
Then have your asking, and be grieved, he's dead;
How you will answer for his worth I know not,
But this I am sure, either he, or you, or both
Were stark mad, else he might have lived
To have given a stronger testimony toth' world
Of what he might have been. He was a man
I knew but in his evening: ten suns after,
〈◊〉 by a tyrant storm our beaten bark
Bulged under us; in which sad parting blow,
He called upon his saint, but not for life,
On you unhappy woman; and whilst all
Sought to preserve their souls, he desperately
Embraced a wave, crying to all that see it,
If any live, go to my fate, that forced me
To this untimely end, and make her happy:
His name was Lovelesse: and I 'scaped the storm.
And now you have my business.
'Tis too much.
Would I had been that storm, he had not perished.
If you'll rail now I will forgive you sir,
Or if you'll call in more, if any more
Come from this ruin, I shall justly suffer
What they can say: I do confess myself
A guilty cause in this. I would say more,
But grief is grown too great to be delivered.
I like this well: these women are strange things.
'Tis somewhat of the latest now to weep,
You should have wept when he was going from you,
And chained him with those tears at home.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Would you had told me then so, these two arms had been his sea.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Trust me you move me much: but say he lived, these were forgotten things again.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Ay, say you so? Sure I should know that voice: this is knavery. I'll fit you for it: were he living sir, I would persuade you to be charitable, ay, and confess we are not all so ill as your opinion holds us. O my friend, what penance shall I pull upon my fault, upon my most unworthy self for this?

lg.l: Leave to love others, 'twas some jealousy
That turned him desperate.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I'll be with you straight: are you wrung there?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: This works amain upon her.

lg.l: I doc confess there is a gentleman
Has born me long good will.

sp.speaker: E. Lo.
sp.p: I do not like that.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: And vowed a thousand services to me; to me, regardless of him: but since fate, that no power can withstand, has taken from me my first and best love, and to weep away my youth is a mere folly: I will show you what I determine sir: you shall know all: call Mr. Welford there: that gentleman I mean to make the model of my fortunes, and in his chaste embraces keep alive the memory of my lost lovely Lovelesse: he is somewhat like him too.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Then you can love?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Yes certain sir.

lg.l: Though it please you to think me hard and cruel,
I hope I shall persuade you otherwise.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I have made myself 〈◊〉 fool.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Would you have spoken with me madam?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Yes Mr. Welford, and I ask your pardon before this gentleman, for being froward: this kiss, and henceforth more affection.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: So, 'tis better I were drowned indeed.

lg.l: This is a sudden passion, God hold it.
This fellow out of his fear sure has
Persuaded her, I'll give him a new suit on't.
A parting kiss: and good sir let me pray you
To wait me in the gallery.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I am in another world. Madam where you please.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo
sp.p: I will to sea, an't shall go hard but I'll be drowned indeed.

lg.l: Now sir you see I am no such hard creature,
But time may win me.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: You have forgotten your lost love,

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p:
Alas sir, what would you have me do? I cannot call him back again with sorrow; I'll love this man as dear, and beshrew
me, I'll keep him far enough from sea: and 'twas told me, now I remember me, by an old wise woman, that my first love should be drowned: and see 'tis come about.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I would she had told you your second should be hanged to, and let that come about: but this is very strange.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Faith sir, consider all, and then I know you'll be of my mind: if 〈◊〉 would redeem him, I would weep still.

lg.l: But say that I were Lovelesse,
And 'scaped the storm, how would you answer this?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why for that gentleman I would leave all the world.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: This young thing too?

lg.l: That young thing too,
Or any young thing else: why I would lose my stare.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Why then he lives still, I am he, your Lovelesse.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: A as I knew it sir, and for that purpose prepared this pageant: get you to your task. And leave these player's tricks, or I shall leave you, indeed I shall. Travel, or know me not.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Will you then marry?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I will not promise, take your choice. Farewell.

lg.l: There is no other purgatory but a woman.
I must do something.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Mistress I am 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You are indeed.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You have so overjoyed me lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Take heed you surfeit not, pray fast and welcome.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: By this light you love me extremely.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: By this, and tomorrow's light, I care not for you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Come, come, you cannot hide it.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Indeed I can, there you shall never find it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I like this mirth well lady

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You shall have more on't.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I must kiss you.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: No fir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Indeed I must.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: What must be, must be; I'll take my leave, you have your parting blow: I pray commend me to those few friends you have, that sent you hither, and tell them, when you 〈◊〉 next, 'twere fit you brought less bravery with you, and more wit, you'll never get a wise else.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Are you in earnest?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Yes faith. Will you eat sir? your horses will be ready straight, you shall have a napkin laid in the buttery for ye.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Do not you love me then?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Yes, for that face.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: It is a good one lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Yes, if it were not warped, the fire in time may mend it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: methinks yours is none of the best lady.

lg.l: No by my troth sir: yet o'my conscience,
You could make shift with it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Come, pray no more of this.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I will not: fare you well. Ho, who's within there? bring out the gentleman's horses, he's in haste; and set some cold meat on the table.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I have too much of that, I thank you lady: take your chamber when you please, there goes a black one with you lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Farewell young man.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You have made me one. Farewell: and may the curse of a great house fall upon thee, I mean the butler. The devil and all his works are in these women: would all of my sex were of my mind, I would make 'em a new lent, and a long one, that flesh might be in more reverence with them.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I am sorry Mr. Welford.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: So am I, that you are here.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: How does my lady use you?

sp.speaker: Wel
sp.p: As I would use you, scurvily.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I should have been more kind sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I should have been undone then. Pray leave me, and look to your sweet meats: hark, your lady calls.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Sir I shall borrow so much time without offending.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You're nothing but offence: for god's love leave me.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: 'Tis strange my lady should be such a tyrant.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: To send you to me. Pray go stitch, good do, you're more trouble to me then a term.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I do not know how my good will, if I said love I lied not, should any way deserve this.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: A thousand ways, a thousand ways: sweet creature let me depart in peace.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: What creature sir? I hope I am a woman.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: A hundred I think by your noise.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Since you are angry sir, I am bold to tell you, that I am a woman, and a rib.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Of a roasted horse.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Construe me that.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
A dog can do it better. Farewell countess, and commend me to your lady: tell her she's proud, and scurvy; and
so I commit you both to your tempter.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Sweet Mr. Welford.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Avoid old Satanus: go daub your ruins, your face looks fouler than a storm: the footman stays you in the lobby lady.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: If you were a gentleman I should know it by your gentle conditions? are these fit words to give a gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: As fit as they were made for ye: sirrah, my horses. Farewell old adage, keep your nose warm, the rheum will make it horn else.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: The blessings of a prodigal young heir be thy companions Welford, marry come up my gentleman, are your gums grown so tender they cannot bite? A skittish filly will be your fortune Welford, and fair enough for such a packsaddle. And I doubt not, (If my aim hold) to see her made too amable to your hand.

div.stage: Enter Yo. Loveless and Comrades, Moorcraft, widow, Savil, and therest.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Save thy brave shoulder, my young puissant knight, and may thy backsword bite them to the bone, that love thee not: thou art an errant man, go on. The circumcised shall fall by thee let land and labour fill the man that tills, thy sword must be thy plough, and Jove it speed. Mecha shall sweat, and Mahomet shall fall, and thy dear name fill up his monument.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: It shall captain, I mean to be a worthy.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: One worthy is too little, thou shalt be all.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Captain I shall deserve some of your love too.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Thou shalt have heart and hand to noble Moorecraft, if thou wilt lend me money. I am a man of garrison, be ruled, and open to me those infernal gates, whence none of thy evil angels pass again, and I will style thee noble; nay don Diego, I'll woe thy infanta for thee, and my knight shall feast her with high meats, and make her apt.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Pardon me captain, you're beside my meaning.

lg.l: No Mr. Moorecraft, 'tis the captain's meaning
I should prepare her for ye.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Or provoke her. Speak my modern man, I say provoke her.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: Captain I say so too, or stir her to it. So says the critics.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p:
But howsoever you expound it sir, she's very welcome,
and this shall serve for witness. And widow, since you're come so happily, you shall deliver up the keys, and free possession of this house; whilst I stand by to ratify.

lg.l: I had rather give it back again believe me,
'Tis a misery to say you had it. Take heed.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: 'Tis past that widow, come, sit down; some wine there: there is a scurvy banquet if we had it. All this fair house is yours sir. Savill.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Are your keys ready, I must ease your burden.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I am ready sir to be undone, when you shall call me to't.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Come come, thou shalt live better.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I shall have less to do, that's all, there's half a dozen of my friends ith' fields, sunning against a bank, with half a breech among 'em, I shall be with 'em shortly. The care and continual vexation of being rich eat up this rascal. What shall become of my poor family? they are no sheep, and they must keep themselves.

lg.l: Drink Mr. Moorecraft, pray be merry all:
Nay and you will not drink there's no society.
Captain speak loud, and drink: widow a word.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Expound her thoroughly knight. Here God a gold, here's to thy fair possessions: be a baron, and a bold one: leave off your tickling of young heirs like trouts, and, let thy chimneys smoke. Feed men of war, live and be honest, and be saved yet.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I thank you worthy captain for your counsel. You keep your chimneys smoking there, your nostrils, and when you can, you feed a man of war: this makes not you a baron, but a bare-one: and how or when you shall be saved, let the clerk o'th company (You have commanded) have a just care of.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: The man is much is much moved. Be not angry sir, but as the poet sings; let your displeasure be a short fury, and go out. You have spoke home, and bitterly, to me sir? Captain take truce the miser is a tart and a witty whoreson.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Poet you feign perdie, the wit-of this man lies in his finger's ends, he must tell all: his tongue fills but his mouth like a neatstongue, and only serves to lick his hungry chaps after a purchase: his brains and brimstone are the devil's diet to a fat usurer's head. To her knight, to her: clap her aboard and stow her. Where's the brave steward?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Here's your poor friend, and Savil sir.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: A way, thou'rt rich in ornaments of nature. First in thy face, thou hast a serious face, a betting, bargaining, and saving face, 〈◊〉 face, pawn it to the usurer; a face to kindle the compassion of the most ignorant and frozen justice.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: 'Tis such, I dare not show it shortly sir.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: By blithe and bonny steward: master Moorecraft, drink to this man of reckoning.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Here's e'en to him.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: The devil guide it downward: would there were in't an acre of the great broom field he bought, to sweep your dirty conscience, or to choke ye, 'tis all one to me usurer.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Consider what I told you, you are young, unapt for worldly business: is it fit one of such tenderness, so delicate, so contrary to things of care, should stir and break her better meditations , in the bare brokage of a brace of angels? or a new kirtle, though it be of satin? Eat by the hope of surfeits, and lie down only in expectation of a morrow that may undo some easy hearted fool, or reach a widow's curses? Let out money, whose use returns the principal? and get out of these troubles, a consuming heir: for such a one must follow necessary, you shall die hated, if not old and miserable; and that possessed wealth that you got with pining, live to see tumbled to another's hands, that is no more akin to you, than you to his cozenage.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Sir you speak well, would God that charity had first begun here.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: 'Tis yet time. Be merry, methinks you want wine there, there's more i'th house: captain, where rests the health?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: It shall go round boy?

sp.speaker: Young Lo
sp.p:
Say you can suffer this, because the end points at much profit, can you so far bow below your blood, below your too much beauty, to be a partner of this fellow's bed, and lie with his diseases? If you can, I will not press you further: yet look upon him: there's nothing in that hidebound usurer; that man of mat, that all decayed, but aches: for you to love, unless his perisht lungs his dry cough, or his scurvy. This is truth, and so far I dare speak yet: he has yet passed cure of physic, spa, or any diet, a primitive pox in his bones; and of my knowledge he has been ten times rowelled: ye may love him; he had a bastard, his own towards issue,
whipped, and then cropped for washing out the roses, in three farthings to make 'em pence.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: I do not like these morals.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: You must not like him then.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: By your leave gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: By my troth sir you are welcome, welcome faith: lord what a stranger you are grown; pray know this gentlewoman, and if you please these friends here: we are merry, you see the worst on's: your house has been kept warm sir:

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
