sp.p: I am glad to hear it brother, pray God you are wise too.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Pray Mr. Moorecraft know my elder brother, and captain do your compliment. Savil, I dare swear is glad at heart 〈◊〉 you: lord, we heard sir you were drowned at sea, and see how luckily things come about?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: This money must be paid again sir?

sp.speaker: Young l. oh
sp.p: No sir, pray keep the sale, 'twill make good tailor's measures? I am well I thank you.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: By my troth the gentleman has stewed him in his own sauce, I shall love him fort.

sp.speaker: Sa
sp.p: I know not where I am, I am so glad: your worship is the welcomest man alive; upon my knees I bid you welcome home: here has been such a hurry, such a din, such dismal drinking, swearing, and whoring, 'thas almost made me mad: we have all hued in a continual Turnbull street; sir blessed be heaven, that sent you safe again. Now shall I eat and go to bed again.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo
sp.p: Brother dismiss these people.

sp.speaker: Young l.
sp.p: Captain be gone a while, meet me at my old rendezvous in the evening, take your small poet with you mr. Moorecraft, you were best go prattle with your learned counsel, I shall preserve your money. I was cozened when time was, we are quit sir.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: better and better still:

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: What is this fellow brother?

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: The thirsty usurer that supped my land off:

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: What does he 〈◊〉 for?

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Sir to b landlord of your house and state: I was hold to make a little sale sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Am I overreached? if there be law, I'll hamper ye.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p:
Prithee be gone, and rail at home, thou art so base 〈◊〉 fool I cannot laugh at thee 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉 comes of cozening, home and spare, care 〈◊〉 till you raise your sums again. If you stir
far in this, I'll have you whipped, your ears nailed for intelligencing, o'th pillory, and your goods forfeit: you are a stale cozener, leave my house: no more.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: A pox upon your house. Come widow, I shall yet hamper this young gamester.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Good twelve 〈◊〉 hundred keep your way, I am not for your diet: marry in your own tribe jow, and get a brokes.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: 'Tis well said widow: will you jog on sir?

lg.l: Yes, I will go, but 'tis no matter whither:
But when I trust a wild fool, and a woman,
May I lend gratis, and build hospitals.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Nay good sir make all even, here's a widow wants your good word for me: she's rich, and may renew me and my fortunes.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I am glad you look before you. Gentlewoman, here is a poor distressed younger brother.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: You do him wrong sir, he's a knight.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I ask your mercy: yet 'tis no matter, his knighthood is no inheritance I take it: whatsoever he is, he's your servant, or would be lady. Faith be not merciless, but make a man; he's young and handsome, though he be my brother, and his observances may deserve your love: he shall not fall for means.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Sir, you speak like a worthy brother: and so much I do credit your fair language, that I shall love your brother: and so love him, but I shall blush to say more.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Stop her mouth. I hope you shall not live to know that hour when this shall be repented. Now brother I should chide, but I'll give no distaste to your fair mistress, I will instruct her in't, and she shall do't: you have been wild, and ignorant, pray mend it.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Sir every day now spring comes on.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: To you, good Mr. Savill, and your office, thus much I have to say: you're from my steward become, first your own drunkard, than his bawd: they say you're excellent grown in both, and perfect: give me your keys sir Savill.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good sir consider who you left me too.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p:
I left you as a curb for, not to provoke my brother's follies: where's the best drink now? come, tell me Savill: where's the soundest whores? Ye old he goat, ye dried ape, ye lame stallion, must you be leading in my house your whores, like fairies dance their night rounds, without fear either of King or constable,
within my walls? Are all my hangings safe? my sheep unsold yet? I hope my plate is currant, I ha' too much on't. What say you to 300. pounds in drink now?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good sir forgive me, and but hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: methinks thou shouldst be drunk still, and not speak, 'tis the more pardonable.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I will sir, if you will have it so.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I thank ye; yes e'en pursue it sir: do you hear? get a whore soon for your recreation: go loose out captain Brokenbreech your fellow, and quarrel, if you dare: I shall deliver these keys to one shall have more honesty, though not so much fine wit sir. Ye may walk and gather cresses sir to cool your liver; there's something for you to begin a diet, you● have the pox else. Speed you well, sir Savill: you may eat at my house to preserve life; but keep no fornications in the stables.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Now must I hang myself, my friends will look for't. Eating and sleeping, I do despise you both now: I will run mad first, and if that get not pity, I'll drown myself, to a most dismal ditty. Exit Savill.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p:
A lass poor gentlewoman, to what a misery hath age brought thee to? to what scurvy fortune? thou that hast been a companion for noble men, and at the worst of those times for gentlemen: now like a broken servingman, must beg for favour to those that would have crawled like pilgrims to my chamber, but for an apparition of me: you that be coming on, make much of fifteen, and so till five and twenty: use your time with reverence, that your profit may arise: it will not tarry with you ecce signum: here was a face, but time that like a sunset eats our youth, plague of his iron teeth, and draw 'em for't, has been a little bolder here then welcome: and now to say the truth I am fit for no man. Old men i' 〈◊〉 house, of fifty, call me Granam; and when they are drunk, e'en then, when Joan and my lady are all one, not one will do me reason. My little Levite hath forsaken
me, his silver sound of cithern quite abolished, his doleful hymns under my chamber window, digested into tedious learning: well fool, you leapt a haddock when you left him: he's a clean man, and a good edifier, and twenty nobles is his state de claro, besides his pigs in posse. To this good homilist I have been ever stubborn, which God forgive me for, and mend my manners: and love, if ever thou hadst care of forty, of such a piece of lape ground, hear my prayer, and fire his zeal so far forth that my faults, in this renewed impression of my love, may show corrected to our gentle reader. Enter Roger.

See how neglectingly he passes by me: with what an equipage canonical, as though he had broke the heart of Bellarmine, or added some thing to the singing brothers. 'tis scorn, I know it, and deserve it. mr. Rogor.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Fair gentlewoman, my name is Roger.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Then gentle Roger.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Ungentle Abigall.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Why Mr. Roger will you set your wit to a weak woman's.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: You are weak indeed: for so the poet sings.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I do confess my weakness sweet sir Roger.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Good my lady's gentlewoman, or my good lady's gentlewoman (This trope is lost to you now) leave your prating, you have a season of your first mother in ye: and surely had the devil been in love, he had been abused too, go Dalida; you make men fools, and wear fig breeches.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Well, well, hard hearted man; dilate upon the weak infirmities of women: these are fit texts: but once there was a time, would I had never seen those eyes, those eyes, those orient eyes.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I they were pearls once with you.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Saving your reverence sir, so they are still.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I do beseech you leave your cogging, what they ate, they are, they serve me without spectacles I thank 'em,

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: O will you kill me?

lg.l: I do not think I can,
You're like a copyhold with nine lives in't.
You were wont to bear a Christian fear about you:
For your own worship's sake.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p:
I was a Christian fool then: do you remember what a dance you led me? how I grew quaumed in love, and was a dunce?
could expound but once a quarter, and then was out too: and then at prayers once (Out of the stinking stir you put me in) I prayed for mine own royal issue. You do remember all this?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: O be as then you were.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I thank you for it; surely I will be wiser Abigall: and as the ethnic poet sings, I will not lose my oil and labour too. You're for the worshipful I take it Abigall.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: O take it so, and then I am for thee.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I like these tears well, and this humbling also, they are symptoms of contrition, as a father saith. If I should fall into my fit again, would you not shake me into a quotidian coxcomb? Would you not use me scurvily again, and give me possets with purging comsets in't? I tell thee gentlewoman, thou hast been harder to me then a long chapter with a pedigree.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: O curate cure me: I will love thee better, dearer, longer, I will do anything, betray the secrets of the main household to thy reformation. My lady shall look lovely on thy learning; and when true time shall point thee for a parson, I will invert thy eggs to penny custards, and thy tithe goose shall graze and multiply.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I am mollified: as well shall testify this faithful kiss: and have a great care mistress, Abigall, how you depress the spirit any more with your rebukes and mocks: for certainly the edge of such a folly cuts itself.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: O sir you have pierced me thorough. Here I vow a recantation to those malicious faults I ever did against you. Never more will I despise your learning never more pin cards and coney tails upon your cassock, never again reproach your reverend nightcap, and call it by the mangy name of murrain, never your reverend person more, and say, you look like one of Baal's priests a hanging; never again, when you say grace, laugh at you, nor put you out at prayers: never cramp you more with the great book of martyrs; nor when you ride, get soap and thistles for you. No my Roger, these faults shall be corrected and amended, as by the tenor of my tears appears.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Now cannot I hold if I should be hanged, I must cry to. Come to thine own beloved, and do even what thou wilt with me, sweet, sweet, Abi. I am thine own for ever: here's my hand, when Ro. proves a recreant, hang him i'th bell-ropes. Ent. la. and Mar.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why how now Mr. Roger, no prayers down with you tonight ? did you hear the bell ring? You are courting, your flock shall fat well for it.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I humbly ask your pardon: I'll clap up prayers (But stay a little) and be with you again.

lg.l: How dare you being so unworthy a fellow,
Presume to come to move me any more?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: What ails the fellow.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: The fellow comes to laugh at you. I tell you lady, I would not for your land, be such a coxcomb, such a whining ass, as you decreed me for when I was last here.

lg.l: I joy to hear you are wise sir, 'tis a rare jewel
In an elder brother: pray be wiser yet.
Methinks I am very wise: I do not come a-wooing ;
Indeed I'll move no more love to your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: What make you here then?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Only to see you, and be merry lady: that's all my business. Faith let's be very merry. Where's little Roger? he's a good fellow: an hour or two well spent in wholesome mirth is worth a thousand of these puling passions. 'tis an ill world for lovers.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: They were never fewer.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I thank God there's one less for me lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You were never any sir.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Till now; and now, I am the prettiest fellow.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You talk like a tailor sir.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: methinks your faces are no such fine things now.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why did you tell me you were wise. Lord what a lying age is this, where will you mend these faces?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: A hog's face soused is worth a hundred of 'em.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Sure you had some sow to your mother.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: She brought such fine white pigs as you: fit for none but parson's lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 'Tis well you will allow us our clergy yet.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: That shall not save you. O that I were in love again with a wish.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: By this light you are a scurvy fellow, pray be gone.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: You know I am a clean skinned man.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Do I know it?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p:
Come, come, you would know it; that's as good: but
not a snap, never long for't, not a snap dear lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Hark ye sir, hark ye, get ye to the suburbs, there's horseflesh for such hounds: will you go sir?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Lord, how I loved this woman, how I worshipped this pretty calf with the white face here: as I live, you were the prettiest fool to play withal, the wittiest little varlet, it would talk: lord how it talked; and when I angered it, it would cry out, and scratch, and eat no meat, and yet would say, go hang.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: It will say so still, if you anger it.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: And when I asked it, if it would be married, it sent me of an errant into France: and would abuse me, and be glad it did so.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Sir, this is most unmanly, pray begone.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: And tw●e (Even when it twittered to be a● me) I was unhandsome.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Have you no manners in you?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: And say my back was melted, when the gods knows 〈◊〉 kept it at a charge: feure Flanders mares would have been easier to me, and a fencer.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You think all this is true now.

lg.l: Faith whether it be or no, 'tis too good for you.
But so much for our mirth: now have at you in earnest.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: There is enough sir, I desire no 〈◊〉.

lg.l: Yes faith, we'll have a cast at your best parts now,
And ●en the devil take the worst.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Pray sir no more, I am not much affected with your commendations: 'tis almost dinner, I know they stay you at the ordinary.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: E'en a short grace, and then I am gone: you are a woman, and the proudest that ever loved a coach: the scornfullest, scurviest, and most 〈◊〉 woman; the greediest to be praised, and never moved, though it be gross and open; the most envious, that at the poor f●me of another's face, would eat your own, and more than is your own, the paint belonging to it: of such a self opinion, that you think none can deserve your glove: and for your malice, you are so excellent, you might have been your tempter's tutor: nay, 〈◊〉 cry.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Your own heart knows you wrong me: I cry for ye?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: You shall before I leave you

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Is all this spoke in earnest?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Yes, and more as soon as I can get it out.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Well, out with't.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: You are, let me see.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: One that has used you with too much respect.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: One that hath used me (Since you will have it so) the basest, the most footboy like, without respect of what I was, or what you might be by me: you have used me, as I would use a jade, ride him off's legs, then turn him into the commons: you have used me with discretion, and I thank ye. If you have many more such pretty servants, pray build an hospital, and when they are old, keep 'em for shame.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I cannot think yet this is serious,

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Will you have more on't?

lg.l: No faith, there's enough if it be true:
Too much by all my part: you are no lover then?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: No, I had rather be a carrier.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why the gods amend all.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Neither do I think there can be such a fellow found i'th world, to be in love with such a froward woman: if there be such, they're mad, Jove comfort 'em. Now you l have all, and I as new a man, as light, and spirited, that I feel myself clean through another creature. O 'tis brave to be ones own man. I can see you now as I would see a picture, sit all day by you and never kiss your hand: hear you sing, and never fall backward; but with as set a temper, as I would hear a fiddler, rise and thank you. I can now keep my money in my purse, that still was gadding out for scarves and waistcoats: and keep my hand from mercers sheepskins finely. I can eat mutton now, and feast myself with my two shillings, and can see a play for eighteen pence again: I can my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: The carriage of this fellow vexes me. Sir, pray let me speak a little private with you, I must not suffer this.

lg.l: Ha, ha, ha, what would you with me?
You will not ravish me? Now, your set speech.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Thou perjured man.

lg.l: Ha, ha, ha, this is a fine exordium:
And why I pray you perjured?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Did you not swear a thousand thousand times you loved me best of all things?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I do confess it: make your best of that.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why do you say, you do not then?

lg.l: Nay 〈◊〉 swear it,
And give sufficient reason, your own usage.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Do you not love me now then?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: No faith.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Did you ever think I loved you dear?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Yes, but I see but rotten fruits on't.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Do not deny your hand, for I must kiss it, and take my last farewell: now let me die so you be happy.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo:
sp.p: I am too foolish: lady, speak dear lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: No let me die.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: O my sister.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: O my lady, help, help.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Run for some rosa-solis.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I have played the fine ass: bend her body, lady, best, dearest, worthiest lady, hear your servant: I am not as I showed: oh wretched fool to fling away the jewel of thy life thus. Give her more air, see she begins to 〈◊〉, sweet mistress hear me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Is my servant well.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: In being yours I am so.

sp.speaker: ●a
sp.p: Then I care not.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: How do ye, reach a chair there: I confess my fault not pardonable, in pursuing thus upon such tenderness my wilful error: but had I known it would have wrought thus with ye, thus strangely; not the world had won me to it, and let not (My best lady) any word spoken to my end disturb your quiet peace: for sooner shall you know a general ruin, than my faith broken. Do not doubt this mistress: for by my life I cannot live without you. Come come, you shall not grieve, rather be angry, and heap infliction on me: I will suffer. O I could curse myself, pray smile upon me. Upon my faith it was but a trick to try you, knowing you loved me dear, and yet strangely that you would never show it, though my means was all humility.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I thank you fine fool for your most fine plot: this was a subtle one, a 〈◊〉 device to have caught dotterels with. Good senseless sir, could you imagine I should swoon for you, and know yourself to be an arrant ass? Ay, 'a discovered one. 'tis quit I thank you sir. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: M●r.
sp.p: Take heed sir, she may chance to swoon again?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Step to her sir, see how she changes colour.

lg.l: I'll go to hell first, and be better welcome.
I am fooled, I do confess it, finely fooled,
Lady fooled madam, and I thank you for it.
Faith' 〈◊〉 not so much worth sir:
But if I know when you come next a birding.
I'll have a stronger noose to hold the woodcock.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I am glad to see you merry, pray laugh on.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Had a hard heart that could not laugh at you sir. ha, ha.

lg.l: Pray sister do not laugh, you'll anger him,
And then he'll 〈◊〉 like a rude 〈◊〉,
That schoolboys had cozened of his apples,
As loud and senseless.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I will not rail.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Faith then let's hear him sister.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Yes you shall hear me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Shall we 〈◊〉 the better for it then?

lg.l: No. He that makes a woman better by his words,
I'll have him sainted: blows will not do it.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: By this light he'll beat us.

lg.l: You do deserve it richly,
And may live to have a beadle do it.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Now he rails.

lg.l: Come 〈◊〉 full folly,
If this be railing, you shall hear me rail.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Pray put it in good words then.

lg.l: The worst are good enough for such a trifle,
Such a proud 〈◊〉 of cobweb lawn.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You 〈◊〉 sir.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I would till the bones cracked, and I had my will.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: We had best muffle him, he grows 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo
sp.p: I would 'twere 〈◊〉 in the next great sickness to have the dogs spared; those harmless creatures, and knock ith' head these hot continual plagues, women, that are more 〈◊〉. I hope the state will think on't.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Are you well sir?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He looks as though he had a grievous fit ath' colic.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 will you cure me?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: He heat a trencher for him.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p:
Dirty December do. Thou with a face as old as erra pater, such a prognosticating nose: thou thing that ten years
since has left to be a woman, outworn the expectation of a bawd; and thy dry bones can reach at nothing now, but gords or ninepins; pray go fetch a trencher, go:

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Let him alone, is cracked:

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I'll see him hanged first, is a beastly fellow, to lose a woman of my breeding thus; I marry is a: would I were a man, I'd make him eat his knave's words.

sp.speaker: Elder L.
sp.p: Tie your she Otter up, good lady folly, she stinks worse than a bear-baiting.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why will you be angry now?

sp.speaker: Elder L.
sp.p: Go paint and purge, call in your kennel with you: you a lady?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Sirrah, look to't against the quarter sessions, if there be good behaviour in the world, I'll have thee bound to it.

sp.speaker: Elder
sp.p: L. You must not seek it in your lady's house then: pray send this ferret home, and spin good Abigall. And madam, that your ladyship may know, in what base manner you have used my service, I do from this hour hate thee heartily: and though your folly should whip you to repentance. and waken you at length to see my wrongs, 'tis not the endeavour of your life shall win me: not all the friends you have in intercession, nor your submissive letters, though they spoke as many tears as words; not your knees grown toth' ground in penitence, not all your state, to kiss you: nor my pardon nor will to give you Christian burial, if you die thus: so farewell. When I am married and made sure, I'll come and visit you again, and vex you lady. By all my hopes I'll be a torment to you, worse than a tedious winter. I know you will recant and sue to me, but save that labour: I'll rather love a fever and continual thirst, rather contract my youth to drink, and safer dote upon quarrels, or take a drawn whore from an hospital, that time, diseases, and Mercury had eaten, than to be drawn to love you.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, pray do, but take heed though.

sp.speaker: Elder L.
sp.p: From thee, false dice, lads. Cowards, and plaguy summers, good lord deliver me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: But hark you servant, hark ye: is he gone? call him aine:

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Hang him Padocke.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Art thou here still? fly, fly, and call my servant, fly or ne'er see me more.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I had rather knit again then see that rascal, but I must do it.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I would be loath to anger him too much: what fine foolery 〈◊〉 this in a woman, to use those men most frowardly they love most? If I should lose him thus, I were rightly served. I hope is not so much himself to take it to'th heart: how now? will he come back?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Never he swears whilst he can hear men say there's any woman living: he swore he wood ha' me first.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Didst thou entreat him wench?

sp.speaker: A●i.
sp.p: As well as I could madam. But this is still your way, to love being absent, and when he's with you, laugh at him and abuse him. There is another way if you could hit on't.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Thou sayest true, get me paper, pen, and ink, I'll write to him, I'd be loath he should sleep in's anger.
Women are most fools, when they think they're wisest.

div.stage: Music. Enter young Loveless and widow, going to be married: with them his comrades.

sp.speaker: Vvi.
sp.p: Pray sir cast off these fellows, as unfitting for your bare knowledge, and far more your company: is't fit such ragamuffins as these are should bear the name of friends? and furnish out a civil house? you're to be married now, and men that love you must expect a course far from your old career: if you will keep 'em, turn 'em toth' stable, and there make 'em grooms: and yet now I consider it, such beggars once set a horse back, you have heard will ride, how far you had best to look to.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Hear you, you that must be lady, pray content yourself and 〈◊〉 upon your carriage soon at night, what dressing will best take your knight, what waistcoat, what cordial will do well i'th morning for him, what tryers have you?

sp.speaker: Vvi.
sp.p: What do you mean sir?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Those that must switch him up: if he start well, fear not but cry s. George, and bear him hard: when you perceive his wind grows hot, and wanting, let him a little down, is fleet ne'er doubt him, and stands sound.

sp.speaker: Vvi.
sp.p: Sir, you hear these fellows?

sp.speaker: Young L.
sp.p: Merry companions, wench, merry companions:

sp.speaker: Uui.
sp.p: To one another let 'em be companions, but good sir not to you: you shall be civil and slip off these base trappings.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: He shall not need, my most sweet lady grocer, if he be civil, not your powdered sugar, nor your reasens shall persuade the captain to live a coxcomb with him: let him be civil and eat i'th arches, and see what will come on't.

sp.speaker: Poet
sp.p: I et him be civil, do: undo him: ay, that's the next way. I will not take (If he be civil once) two hundred pounds a year to live with him: be civil? there's a trim persuasion.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: If thou beest civil knight, as Jove defend it, get thee another nose, that will be pulled off by the angry boys, for thy conversion: the children thou shalt get on this civilian cannot inherit by the law, they're ethnics, and all thy sport mere moral lechery: when they are grown having but little in 'em, they may prove haberdashers, or gross grocers, like their dear dam there: prithee be civil knight, in time thou mayst read to thy household and be drunk once a year: this would show finely.

sp.speaker: Young L.
sp.p: I wonder sweet heart you will offer this, you do not understand these gentlemen: I will be short and pithy: I had rather cast you off by the way of charge: these are creatures, that nothing goes to the maintenance of but corn and water. I will keep these fellows just in the competency of two hens:

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: If you can cast it so sir, you have my liking; if they eat less, I should not be offended: but how these, sir, can live upon so little as corn and water. I am unbelieving.

sp.speaker: Young L.
sp.p: Why prithee sweet heart what's your ale? is not that corn and water my sweet widow?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: I but my sweet knight, where's the meat to this, and clothes that they must look for?

sp.speaker: Young L.
sp.p:
In the short sentence ale, is all included: meat, drink, and cloth: these are no ravening footmen, no fellows that at ordinaries dare 〈◊〉 their eighteen pence thrice out before they rise, and yet go hungry to play, and crack more nuts then would suffice a dozen squirrels; besides the din,
which is damnable: I had rather rail, and be confined to a boat maker, than hue among such rascals; these are people of such a clean discretion in their diet, of such a moderate sustenance, that they sweat if they but smell hot meat. Porridge is poison, they hate a kitchen as they hate a counter, and show 'em but a featherbed they swoon. Ale is their 〈◊〉, and their drinking surely, which keeps their bodies clear, and soluble. Bread is a binder, and for that abolished even in their ale, whose lost room fills an apple, which is more air, and of 〈◊〉 nature. The rest they take, is little, and that little, as little easy: for like strict men of order, they do correct their bodies with a bench, or a poor stubborn table; if a chimney 〈◊〉 it 〈◊〉 with some few broken rushes, they are in down: when they are sick, that's drunk, they may have fresh shaw, else they do despise these worldly pamperings. For their poor apparel, 'tis worn out to the diet; new they seek none, and if a man should offer, they are angry: scarce to be reconciled again with him: you shall not hear 'em ask one a cast doublet, once in a year, which is a modesty befitting my poor friends: you see their 〈◊〉 poe, though slender, competent: for shirts I take it, they are things worn out of their remembrance. Lousy they will be, when they list, and mangy, which shows a fine variety: and then to cure 'em, a tanner's limepit, which is little charge, two dogs, and these; these two may be cured for three pence.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: You have half persuaded me, pray use your pleasure: and my good friends since I do know your diet, I'll take an order, meat shall not offend you, you shall have ale.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: We ask no more, let it be mighty, lady: and if we perish, than our own sins on us.

sp.speaker: Young l.
sp.p: Come forward gentlemen, to church my boys, when we have done, I'll give you cheer in bouls.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p:
This senseless woman vexes me toth' heart, she will not from my memory: would she were a man for one two hours, that I might beat her. If I had been 〈◊〉, old, or t'had
been an even lay she might have scorned me: but to be young, and by this light I think as proper as the proudest; made as clean, as straight, and strong backed; means and manners equal with the best cloth of silver sir i'th kingdom: but these are things at some time of the moon, below the cut of canvas: sure she has some mecching rascal in her house, some hind, that she hath seen bear (Like another Milo) quarters of malt upon his back, and sing with't, thrash all day, and ith' evening in his stockings, strike up a hornpipe, and there stink two hours, and never a whit the worse man; these are they, these 〈◊〉 behind rascals that undo us all. Would I had been a carter, or a coachman, I had done the deed ere this time:

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Sir there's a gentleman without would speak with you:

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Bid him come in:

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: By your leave sir.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: You are welcome, what's your will sir?

sp.speaker: W●l.
sp.p: Have you forgotten me?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I do not much remember you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You must sir. I am that gentleman you pleased to wrong, in your disguise I have inquired you out.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I was disguised indeed sir if I wronged you. Pray where and when?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: In such a lady's house sir: I need not name her.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I do remember you: you seemed to be a suitor to that lady:

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: If you remember this, do not forget how scurvily you used me: that was no place to quarrel in, pray you think of it: if you be honest you dare fight with me, without more viging, else I must provoke ye:

sp.speaker: ●ld. Lo.
sp.p:
Sir I dare fight, but never for a woman, I will not have her in my cause, she's mortal and so is not my anger: if you have brought a nobler subject for our swords, I am for you: in this I would be loath to 〈◊〉 my finger. And where you say I wronged you, 〈◊〉 so far from my profession, that 〈◊〉 my fears, to do wrong is the greatest: credit me we have been both abused. (Not by ourselves, for that I ho●d a spleen no 〈◊〉 of malice, and may with man enough be lest forgotten,) but by that wilful, 〈◊〉 piece of hatred, that much 〈◊〉 lady: for whose
sake, if we should leave our reason, and run on upon our sense, like rams: the little world of good men would laugh at us, and despise us, fixing upon our desperate memories the mever-worn out names of fools, and 〈◊〉. Sir 'tis not fear, but reason makes me tell you: in this I had rather help you sir, then hurt you, and you shall find it, though you throw yourself into as many dangers as she offers, though you redeem her lost name every day, and find her out new honours with your sword, you shall but be her mitth, as I have been.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I ask you mercy sir, you have ta'en my edge off: yet I would fain be even with this lady.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: In which I'll be your helper: we are two, and they are two: two sisters, rich alike, only the elder has the prouder dowry: in troth I pity this disgrace in you, yet of mine own I am 〈◊〉: do but follow my counsel, and I'll pawn my spirit, we'll overreach 'em yet; the means is this.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Sir there's a gentlewoman will needs speak with you: I cannot keep her out, she's entered sir:

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: It is the waiting woman, pray be not seen: sirrah hold her in discourse awhile: hark in your ear, go, and dispatch it quickly, when I come in I'll tell you all the project.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I care not which I have.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Away, 'tis done, she must not see you: now lady Gwiniver, what news with you?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Pray leave these frumps sir, and receive this letter.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: From whom good vanity?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: 'Tis from my lady sir: alas good soul, she cries and takes on:

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Does she so good soul? would she not have a caudle? does she send you with your fine oratory goody Tully to tie me to belief again? Bring out the cat hounds, I'll make you 〈◊〉 a tree whore, then with my tiller bring down your gibship, and then have you cast, and hung up ith' warren.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I am no beast sir: would you knew it:

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Would I did, for I am yet very doubtful: what will you say now?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Nothing not I:

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Art thou a woman, and say nothing?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Unless you'll hear me with more moderation; I c● speak wise enough:

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: And loud enough: will your lady love me?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: It seems so by her letter, and her lamentations: but you are such another man:

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Not such another as I was, Mumps; nor will not be: I'll read her fine epistle: ha, ha, ha: is not thy mistress mad?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: For you she will be, 'tis a shame you should use a poor gentlewoman so untowardly: she loves the ground you tread on: and you (Hard heart) because she jested with you, mean to kill her: 'tis a fine conquest as they say:

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Hast thou so much moisture in thy whitleather hide yet, that thou canst cry? I would have sworn thou hadst been touchwood five year since: nay let it rain, thy face chops for a shower like a dry dunghill.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I'll not endure this ribaldry: farewell ith' devil's name: if my lady die, I'll be sworn before a jury, thou art the cause on't:

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Do Maukin do: deliver to your lady from me this: I mean to see her, if I have no other business; which before I'll want to come to her, I mean to go seek birds nests: yet I may come too: but if I come, from this door till I see her, will I think how to rail vildly at her; how to vex her, and make her cry so much, that the physician if she fall sick upon't shall want v●yne to find the cause by: and she remediless die in her heresy: farewell old adage, I hope to see the boys make potguns on thee.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Thou'rt a vile man; God bless my issue from thee.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Thou hast but one, and that's in thy left crupper, that makes thee hobble so; you must be ground ith' breech like a top, you'll ne'er spin well else: farewell Fitchcock.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p:
Is it not strange that every woman's will should track out new ways to disturb herself? if I should call my reason to account, it cannot answer why I stop myself from mine own wish; and stop the man I love from his; and every hour repent again, yet still go on: I know 'tis like a man, that wants his natural sleep, and growing dull, would gladly give the remnant of his life for two hours rest: yet through his frowardness, will rather choose to watch another man.
Drowsy as he, then take his own repose. All this I know: yet a strange peevishness and anger, not to have the power to do things unexpected, carries me away to mine own ruin had rather die sometimes than not disgrace in public him whom people think I love, and do't with oaths, and am in earnest then: oh what are we! Men, you must answer this, that do obey such things as we command. How now? what news?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Faith madam none worth hearing.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Is he not come?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: No truly.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Nor has he writ?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Neither. I pray God you have not undone yourself:

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why, but what says he?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Faith he talks strangely:

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: How strangely?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: First at your letter he laughed extremely:

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: What in contempt?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: He laughed monstrous loud, as he would die, and when you wrote it, I think you were in no such merry mood, to provoke him that way: and having done he cried alas for her, and violently laughed again.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Did he?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Yes till I was angry:

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Angry, why? why wert thou angry? he did do but well, I did deserve it, he had been a fool, an unfit man for any one to love, had he not laughed thus at me: you were angry, that showed your folly; I shall love him more for that, than all that 〈◊〉 he did before: but said he nothing else?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Many uncertain things: he said though you had mocked him, because you were a woman, he could wish to do you so much favour as to see you: yet he said, he knew you rash, and was loath to offend you with the sight of one, whom now he was bound not to leave.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: What one was that?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I know not, but truly I do fear there is a making up there: for I heard the servants, as I passed by some, whisper such a thing: and as I came back through the hall, there were two or three clerks writing great conveyances in haste, which they said were for their mistress jointure.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 〈◊〉 very like and fit it should be so, for he does think, and reasonably think, that I should keep him with my idle tricks for ever 〈◊〉 he married.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: At last he said, it should go hard but he would see you for your satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: All we that are called women, know as well as men, it were a far more noble thing to grace where we are graced, and give respect there where we are respected: yet we practise a wilder course, and never bend our eyes on men with pleasure, till they find the way to give us a neglect: than we, too late, 〈◊〉 the loss of what we might have had, and dote to death.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Sister yonder's your servant, with a gentlewoman with him.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Close at the door.

lg.l: Alas I am undone, I fear he is betrothed.
What kind of woman is she?
A most ill favoured one, with her masque on:
And how her face should mend the rest I know not.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: But yet her mind is of a milder stuff than mine was.

div.stage: Enter fld Loveless, and Welford in woman's apparel.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Now I see him, if my heart swell not again (Away thou woman's pride) so that I cannot speak a gentle word to him, let me not live.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: By your leave here.

lg.l: How now, what new trick invites you hither?
Have you a fine device again?
Faith this is the finest device I have now:
How dost thou sweet heart?
Why very well, so long as I may please
You my dear lover: I nor can, nor will
Be ill when you are well, well when you are ill.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: O thy sweet temper: what would I have given, that lady had been like thee: seest thou her? that face (My love) joined with thy humble mind, had made a wench indeed.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Alas my love, what God hath done, I dare not think to mend: I use no paint, nor any drugs of art, my hands and face will show it.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why what thing have you brought to show us there? do you take money for it?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: A godlike thing, not to be bought for money: 'tis my mistress: in whom there is no passions, nor no scorn: what I will is for law; pray you salute her.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Salute her? by this good light I would not kiss her for half my wealth.

lg.l: Why, why pray you?
You shall see me do't afore you: look you.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Now fie upon thee, a beast would not have done I would not kiss thee of a month to gain a kingdom.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Marry you shall not be troubled.

lg.l: Why was there ever such a Meg as this?
Sure thou art mad.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I was mad once, when I loved pictures: for what 〈◊〉 shape and colours else, but pictures? in that tawny hide there lies an endless mass of virtues; when all your red and white ones want it.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: And this is she you are to marry, is't not?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Yes indeed is●.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: God give you joy.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Amen.

lg.l: I thank you, as unknown, for your good wish.
The like to you, whenever you shall wed.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: O gentle spirit.

lg.l: You thank me? I pray
Keep your breath nearer you, I do not like it.
I would not willingly offend at all:
Much less a lady of your worthy parts.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Sweet, sweet.

lg.l: I do not think this woman can by nature be thus,
Thus ugly: sure she's some common strumpet,
Deformed with exercise of sin.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: O sir believe not this: for heaven so comfort me as I am free from foul pollution with any man: my honour ta'en away, I am no woman.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Arise my dearest soul: I do not credit it. Alas, I fear her tender heart will break with this reproach: fie that you know no more civility to a weak virgin. 'tis no matter sweet, let her say what she will, thou art not worse to me, and therefore not at all: be careless.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: For all things else I would, but for mine honour: methinks .

lg.l: Alas, thine honour is not stained.
Is this the business that you sent for me about?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Faith sister you are much to balm, to use a woman, whatsoever she be, thus: we salute her: you are welcome hither.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I humbly thank you.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p:
Mild still as the dove, for all these injuries. Come, shall
we go, I love thee not so ill to keep thee here a jesting stock. Adieu to the world's end.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why whither now?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Nay you shall never know, because you shall not find me.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I pray let me speak with you.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: 'Tis very well: come.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I pray you let me speak with you.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Yes for another mock.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: By heaven I have no mocks: good sir a word.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Though you deserve not so much at my hands, yet if you be in such earnest, I will speak a word with you: but I beseech you be brief; for in good faith there's a parson, and a licence stay for us i'th church all this while: and you know 'tis night.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Sir, give me hearing patiently, and whatsoever I have heretofore spoke jestingly, forget: for as I hope for mercy anywhere , what I shall utter now is from my heart, and as I mean.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Well, well, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Was not I once your mistress, and you my servant?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: O 'tis about the old matter.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Nay good sir stay me out: I would but hear you excuse yourself, why you should take this woman, and leave me.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Prithee why not, deserves she not as much as you?

lg.l: I think not, if you will look
With an indifferency up on us both.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Upon your faces, 'tis true: but if judicially we shall cast our eyes upon your minds, you are a thousand women of her in worth: she cannot sound in jest, nor set her lover tasks, to show her peevishness, and his affection: nor cross what he says, though it be canonical. She's a good plain wench, that will do as I will have her, and bring me lusty boys to throw the sledge, and lift at pigs of lead: and for a wife, she's far beyond you: what can you do in a household, to provide for your issue, but lie a-bed and get 'em? your business is to dress you, and at idle hours to eat; when she can do a thousand profitable things: she can do pretty well in the pastry, and knows how pullen should be crammed: she cuts cambric at a thread: weaves bonelace, and quilts balls: and what are you good for?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Admit it true, that she were far beyond me in all respects, does that give you a licence to forswear yourself?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Forswear myself, how?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Perhaps you have forgotten the innumerable oaths you have uttered in disclaiming all for wives but me: I'll not remember you: God give you joy.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Nay but conceive me, the intent of oaths is ever understood. Admit I should protest to such a friend, to see him at his lodging tomorrow: divines would never hold me perjured, if I were struck blind, or he hid him where my diligent search could not find him: so there were no cross act of mine own in't. Can it be imagined I meant to force you to marriage, and to have you whether you will or no?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Alas you need not. I make already tender of myself, and than you are forsworn.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Some sin I see indeed must necessarily fall upon me, as whosoever deals with women shall never utterly avoid it: yet I would choose the least ill; which is to forsake you, that have done me all the abuses of a malignant woman, contemned my service, and would have held me prating about marriage, till I had been past getting of children: then her that hath forsook her family, and put her tender body in my hand, upon my word.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Which of us swore you first to?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo:
sp.p: Why to you.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Which oath is to be kept then.

lg.l: I prithee do not urge my sins unto me,
Without I could amend 'em.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why you may by wedding me.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: How will that satisfy my word to her?

lg.l: 'Tis not to be kept, and needs no satisfaction,
'Tis an error fit for repentance only.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Shall I live to wrong that tender hearted virgin so? It may not be.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why may it not be?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I swear I had rather marry thee then her: but yet mine honesty.

lg.l: What honesty? 'tis more preserved this way:
Come, by this light servant thou shalt, I'll kiss thee on't.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: This kiss indeed is sweet, pray God no sin lie under it.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: There is no sin at all, try but another.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: O my heart.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Help sister, this lady swoons.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: How do you?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why very well, if you be so.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Sure a quiet mind lives not in any woman: I shall do 〈◊〉 most ungodly thing. Hear me one word more, which by all my hopes I will not alter. I did make an oath when you delayed me so; that this very night I would be married. Now if you will go without delay, suddenly, as late as it is, with your own minister to your own chapel, I'll wed you, and to bed.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: A match dear servant.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: For if you should forsake me now, I care not, she would not though for all her injuries, such is her spirit, if I be not ashamed to kiss her now I part, may I not live.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I see you go, as slily as you think to steal away: yet I will pray for you; all blessings of the world light on you two, that you may live to be an aged pair. All curses on me if I do not speak what I do wish indeed.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: If I can speak to purpose to her, I am a villain.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Servant away.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sister, will you marry that inconstant man? think you he will not cast you off tomorrow, to wrong a lady thus, looked she like dirt, 'twas basely done. May you ne'er prosper with him.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Now God forbid, alas I was unworthy, so I told him.

lg.l: That was your modesty, too good for him.
I would not see your wedding for a world.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Choose, choose, come Yonglove.
sp.stage: Ex. la, El. lo. And Yong.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Dry up your 〈◊〉 forsooth, you shall not think we are all uncivil, all such beasts as these. Would I knew how to give you a revenge.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: So would not I: no let me suffer truly, that I desire.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pray walk in with me, 'tis very late, and you shall stay all night: your bed shall be no worse than mine; I wish I could but do you right.

lg.l: My humble thanks:
God grant I may but live to quit your love.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Did your master send for me Savil?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Yes he did send for your worship sir.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Do you know the business?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p:
Alas sir I know nothing, nor am employed beyond my
hours of eating. My dancing days are done sir.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: What art thou now then.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: If you consider me in little, I am with your worship's reverence sir, a rascal: one that upon the next anger of your brother, must raise a sconce by the high way, and sell switches. My wife is learning new sir to weave inkle.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: What dost thou mean to do with thy children Savill?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: My eldest boy is half a rogue already, he was born bursten, and your worship knows, that is a pretty step to men's capassions. My youngest boy I purpose sir to bind for ten years to a jailer, to draw under him, that he may show us mercy in his function.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Your family is quartered with discretion: you are resolved to cant then: where Savil shall your scene lie.

lg.l: Beggar's must be no choosers:
In every place (I take it) but the stocks.
This is your drinking, and your whoring Savil,
I told you of it, but your heart was hardened.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: 'Tis true, you were the first that told me of it, I do remember yet in tears, you told me you would have whores, and in that passion sir, you broke our thus; thou miserable man, repent, and brew three strikes more in a hogshead. 'tis noon ere we be drunk now, and the time can tarry for no man.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: You're grown a bitter gentleman. I see misery can can clear your head better than mustard. I'll be a suitor for your keys again sir.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Will you but be so gracious to me sir? I shall be bound.

lg.l: You shall sir,
To your bunch again, or I'll miss foully.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Save you gent. save you.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Now polecat, what young rabbits nest have you to draw?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Come, pray thee be familiar knight.

sp.speaker: Young Lo!
sp.p: Away fox, I'll send for terriers for you.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Thou art wide yet: I'll keep thee company.

lg.l: I am about some business; indentures,
If ye follow me I'll beat you: take heed,
As I live I'll cancel your 〈◊〉.
Thou art cozened now, I am no usurer:
what poor fellow's this?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I am poor indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Give him money knight.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Do you begin the offering.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: There poor fellow, here's an angel for thee.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Art thou in earnest Moorcraft?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Yes faith knight. I'll follow thy example: thou hadst land and thousands, thou spendst, and flungst away, and yet it flows in double: I purchased, wrung, and wierdrawed for my wealth, lost, and was cozened: for which I make a vow, to try all the ways above ground. but I'll find a constant means to riches without curses.

lg.l: I am glad of your conversion Mr. Moorcraft:
You're in a fair course, pray pursue it still.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Come, we are all gallants now, I'll keep thee company; here honest fellow, for this gentleman's sake, there's two angels more for thee.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: God quit you sir, and keep you long in this mind.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Wilt thou persever?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Till I have a penny. I have brave clothes a making, and two horses; canst thou not help me to a match knight, I'll lay a a thousand pound upon my crop-ear.

lg.l: Foot this is stranger than an Afrique monster,
There will be no more talk of the cleave wars
While this lasts, come, I'll put thee into blood.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Would all his damned tribe were as tender hearted. I beseech you let this gent. join with you in the recovery of my keys; I like his good beginning sir, the whilst I'll pray for both your worships.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: He shall sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Shall we go noble knight? I would fain be acquainted.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: I'll be your servant sir.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Faith my sweet lady, I have caught you now, maugre your subtleties, and fine devises, be coy again now.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 〈◊〉 sweetheart tell true.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: By this light, by all the pleasures I have had this night, by your lost maidenhead, you are cozened merely. I have cast beyond your wit. That gent. is your retainer Welford.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: It cannot be so.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p:
Your sister has found it so, or I mistake: mark how she
blushes when you see her next. Ha, ha, ha, I shall not travel now, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Prithee sweet heart be quiet, thou hast angered me at heart.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I'll please you soon again.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Welford.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I Welford, he's a young handsome fellow, well bred and landed: your sister can instruct you in his good parts better than I by this time.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Uds'foot, am I fetched over thus?

lg.l: Yes i'faith.
And over shall be fetched again, never fear it.
I must be patient, though it torture me:
You have got the sun sir.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: And the moon too, in which I'll be the man.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: But had I known this, had I but surmised it, you should have hunted three trains more, before you had come to'th course, you should have hanckt o'th bridle, sir, i'faith.

lg.l: I knew it, and mined with you, and so blew you up.
Now you may see the gentlewoman: stand close.
For god's sake sir be private in this business,
You have undone me else. O God, what have I done?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: No harm I warrant thee.

lg.l: How shall I look upon my friends again?
With what face?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why e'en with that: 'tis a good one, thou canst not find a better: look upon all the faces thou shalt see there, and you shall find 'em smooth still, fair still, sweet still, and to your thinking honest: those have done as much as you have yet, or dare do mistress, and yet they keep no stir.

lg.l: Good sir go in, and put your woman's clothes on.
If you be seen thus, I am lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I'll watch you for that mistress: I am no fool, here will I tarry till the house be up and witness with me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Good dear friend go in.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
To bed again if you please, else I am fixed here, till there be notice taken what I am, and what I have done: if you could juggle me into my womanhood again, and so cog me out of your company, all this would be forsworn, and I again an asinego, as your sister left me. No, I'll have it known and published; then if
you'll be a whore, forsake me, and be shamed: and when you can hold out no longer, marry some cast Cleve captain, and sell bottle-ale.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I dare not stay sir, use me modestly, I am your wife.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Go in, I'll make up all.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I'll be a witness to your naked truth sir: this is the gentlewoman, prithee look upon him, this is he that made me break my faith sweet: but thank your sister, she hath soldered it.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: What a dull ass was I, I could not see this wencher from a wench: twenty to one, if I had been but tender like my sister, he had served me such a slippery trick too.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Twenty to one I had.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I would have watched you sir, by your good patience, for ferreting in my ground.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Ye have been with my sister.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Yes, to bring.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: An heir into the world he means.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: There is no chafing now.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I have had my part on't: I have been chafed this three hours, that's the least, I am reasonable cool now.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Cannot you fare well, but you must cry roast-meat?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: He that fares well, and will not bless the founders, is either surfeited, or ill taught, lady: for mine own part, I have found so sweet a diet, I can commend it, though I cannot spare it.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: How like you this dish, Welford, I made a supper on't, and fed so heartily, I could not sleep.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: By this light, had I but scented out your train, ye had slept with a bare pillow in your arms, and kissed that, or else the bedpost, for any wife ye had got this twelvemonth yet: I would have vexed you more than a tired post-horse: and been longer bearing, then ever aftergame at Irish was. Lord, that I were unmarried again.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Lady, I would not undertake ye, were you again a haggard, for the best cast of sore ladies i'th kingdom: you were ever tickle footed, and would not truss round?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Is she fast?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: She was all night locked here boy.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Then you may lure her without fear of losing: take off her cranes. You have a delicate gentlewoman to your sister: lord what a pretty fury she was in, when she perceived I was a man: but I thank God I satisfied her scruple, without the parson o'th town.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: What did ye?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Madam, can you tell what we did?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: She has a shrewd guess at it I see by her.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Well you may mock us: but my large gentlewoman, my Mary Ambree, had I but seen into you, you should have had another bedfellow, fitter a great deal for your itch.

lg.l: I thank you lady, methought it was well,
You are so curious.

div.stage: Enter young Loveless, his lady, Moorecraft, Savill and two serving-men.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Get on your doublet, here comes my brother.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Good morrow brother, and all good to your lady.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: God save you, and good morrow to you all.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Good morrow. Here's a poor brother of yours.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Fie how this shames me.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Prithee good fellow help me to a cup of beer.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: I will sir,

lg.l: Brother what make you here? will this lady do?
Will she? is she not nettled still?
No, I have cured her.
Mr. Welford, pray know this gentleman, is my brother.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sir, I shall long to love him.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: I shall not be your debtor sir. But how is't with you?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: As well as may be man ; I am married: your new acquaintance hath her sister: and all's well.

lg.l: I am glad on't. Now my pretty lady sister,
How do you find my brother?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Almost as wild as you are.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: 'A will make the better husband: you have tried him?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Against my will sir.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: He'll make your will amends soon, do not doubt it. But sir, I must entreat you to be better known to this converted Jew here.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Here's beer for you sir.

lg.l: And here's for you an angel:
Pray buy no land, 'twill never prosper sir.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Bless you, and then I'll tell: he's turned gallant.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Gallant?

lg.l: I gallant, and is now called, cutting Moorecraft:
the reason I'll inform you, at more leisure,

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: O good sir let me know him presently.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: You shall hug one another.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Sir I must keep you company.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: And reason.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Cutting Moorcraft faces about. I must present another.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: As many as you will sir, I am for 'em.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sir I shall do you service.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I shall look for't in good faith sir.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Prithee good sweetheart kiss him.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Who, that fellow?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Sir will it please you to remember me: my keys good sir.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: I'll do it presently.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: Come thou shalt kiss him for our sport's sake.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Let him come on then, and do you hear, do not instruct me in these tricks, for you may repent it.

lg.l: That at my peril. Lusty Mr. Moorecraft,
Here is a lady would salute you.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: She shall not lose her longing sir: what is she?

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: My wife sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: She must be then my mistress.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Must I sir:

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: O yes, you must.

lg.l: And you must take this ring, a poor pawn,
Of some fifty pound.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo:
sp.p: Take it by any means, 'tis lawful prize.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Sir I shall call you servant.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I shall be proud on't: what fellow's that:

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: My lady's coachman.

lg.l: There's something. (My friend) for you to buy whips,
And for you sir, and you sir.
Under a miracle this is the strangest,
I ever heard of.
What shall we play, or drink? what shall we do?
Who will hunt with me for a hundred pound?
Stranger and stranger!
Sir you shall find sport after a day or two.
Sir I have a suit unto you,
Concerning your old servant Savill.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: O, for his keys, I know it,

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Now sir, strike in.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Sir I must have you grant me.

lg.l: 'Tis done sir, take your keys again:
But hark you Savill, leave of the motions
Of the flesh, and be honest, or else you shall graze again.
I'll try you once more.
If ever I be taken drunk, or whoring,
Take off the biggest key i'th bunch, and open
My head with it sir: I humbly thank your worships.
Nay then I see we must keep holidayEnt. Roger, and Abigall.
Here's the last couple in hell.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Joy be amongst you all.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why how now sir, what is the meaning of this emblem?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Marriage an't like your worship.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Are you married?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: As well as the next priest could do it, madam.

sp.speaker: Elder Lo.
sp.p: I think the signs in gemini here's such coupling.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sir Roger, what will you take to lie from your sweetheart tonight ?

sp.speaker: Ro
sp.p: Not the best benefice in your worship's gift sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: A whoreson, how he swells.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: How many times tonight sir Roger?

lg.l: Sir you grow scurrilous:
What I shall do, I shall do: I shall not need your help.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: For horse flesh Roger.

lg.l: Come prithee be not angry, 'tis a day
Given wholly to our mirth.
It shall be so sir: sir Roger and his bride,
We shall entreat to be at our charge.
Welford get you to church: by this light,
You shall not lie with her again, till you're married.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I am gone.

lg.l: To every bride I dedicate this day:
Six healths a piece, and it shall go hard,
But every one a jewel: come be mad boys.
Thou'rt in a good beginning: come who leads?
Sir Roger, you shall have the van: lead the way:
Would every dogged wench had such a day. Exeunt.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
